questions.text: Which of the following nerves pierces the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.solution:
• Clavipectoral fascia is a fibrous sheet situated deep to the clavicular portion of the pectoralis major muscle.
  • It extends from the clavicle above to the axillary fascia below.
  • Its upper part splits to enclose the subclavius muscle. The posterior lamina is fused to the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia and to the axillary sheath.
  • Inferiorly, the clavipectoral fascia splits to enclose the pectoralis minor muscle.
  • The clavipectoral fascia is pierced by the following structures, which can be remembered with the following mnemonic:
    • Cephalic vein
    • Acromiothoracic artery ( Thoracoacromian artery)
    • Lateral pectoral nerve
    • Lymphatics passing from the breast and pectoral region to the apical group of axillary lymph nodes

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page Number-47.

questions.text: Manjula, a 47-year-old woman, presents with hot flushes after her menstruation stopped. 'Hot flushes' can be relieved by the administration of which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
• Hot flushes are common vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause. Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT), particularly estrogen therapy, is an effective means to relieve these symptoms.
  • Ethinyl estradiol, a synthetic form of estrogen, is commonly used in HRT to alleviate menopausal symptoms, prevent osteoporosis, and maintain the quality of life in menopausal females.

questions.text: A 25 year old lady has bilateral conductive hearing loss since 4 years which worsened during pregnancy. The hearing loss is gradually progressive in nature. She is also mentioning that she hears better in noisy areas. Type of impedance audiometry curve expected in this case will be?
questions.solution:
This is a case of otosclerosis. ( As Impedance audiogram). The features are:

  • Hearing loss (conductive and bilateral) gradually progressive, made worse by pregnancy.
  • Hearing is better in noisy than in quiet surroundings (Paracusis willisii).

Reference - Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number 29,103,104.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl presented with patchy hair loss over the scalp. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Trichotillomania (TTM) also known as hair-pulling disorder, is a part of OCD and is thought to be largely related to anxiety disorders. More common in females of adolescent age group. Classical tonsular appearance (Friar tuck appearance). Sometimes traumatic pulling of hair can lead to bleeding.
  • Trichoscopy of trichotillomania is characterized by the presence of hairs broken at different lengths, black dots, trichoptilosis, coiled hairs, flame hairs, V-sign and tulip hairs.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page Number-716.

questions.text: Census method used in India is:
questions.solution:
The Census method used in India is primarily based on the De Jure system.

  • De Jure System:
    • In the De Jure system, individuals are counted based on their legal status or residency at a particular location, irrespective of whether they are physically present there during the Census period.
    • This method is suitable for countries like India, where large populations are mobile, and people might be absent from their usual place of residence during the Census period due to various reasons such as work, travel, or temporary relocation.
    • India's Census enumerators visit households and record information about individuals based on their legal residence, including those who may be away at the time of the Census.
    • The De Jure system ensures a comprehensive count of the population, including individuals who are temporarily absent but legally residents of a particular area.
  • Reasons for choosing De Jure System in India:
    • India has a vast and diverse population with significant internal migration patterns. Many people move within the country for employment, education, or other reasons.
    • Implementing a De Jure system allows the census to capture the entire population, including those who might be away from their usual place of residence during the census period.
    • It ensures that individuals are not excluded from the census count merely because they are temporarily absent, thus providing a more accurate representation of the population.

(a) Why Not De Facto System:

  • In a De Facto system, individuals are counted based on their physical presence at the time of the census.
  • This method may not be suitable for countries like India due to its high levels of internal migration. It could result in undercounting certain segments of the population, particularly migrant workers or students who might be away from their usual place of residence during the Census period.
  • Exclusively using a De Facto system could lead to inaccuracies in the census data and hinder effective planning and resource allocation.

(b) Why Not Both:

  • While some countries may employ a combination of De Jure and De Facto methods, India primarily relies on the De Jure system due to its specific demographic and geographic characteristics.
  • Implementing both methods simultaneously might introduce complexity and potential inconsistencies in the Census data, making it challenging to ensure accuracy and reliability.

(c) Why Not None:

  • Not employing any Census method would result in a lack of official population data, which is essential for government planning, policy formulation, resource allocation, and various socio-economic activities.
  • Conducting a Census using a recognised method is crucial for maintaining accurate demographic records and facilitating evidence-based decision-making at both national and local levels.

In conclusion, India predominantly uses the De Jure system for its census method due to the country's demographic complexity, high levels of internal migration, and the need to ensure a comprehensive count of the population. This method helps capture the entire population, including those temporarily absent, thereby providing a more accurate representation of India's diverse populace.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of fatigue, weight gain, and constipation over the past few months. She reports feeling cold most of the time and has noticed her skin becoming dry and coarse. On examination, her skin appears pale and cool to touch. There is puffiness around her eyes, and her voice is hoarse. Laboratory investigations reveal
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH): 20 mIU/L (normal range, 0.34-4.25 mIU/L)
Thyroxine (T4), free: 4.0 pmol/L (normal 10.3-21.9 pmol/L)
What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, and which biochemical pathway is primarily affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Elevated TSH levels indicate primary hypothyroidism, while low levels of free T4 confirm thyroid hormone deficiency.
  • The biochemical pathway primarily affected in hypothyroidism is the "Thyroid hormone synthesis pathway."
  • Hypothyroidism is characterized by decreased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones (thyroxine - T4 and triiodothyronine - T3) due to impaired function of the thyroid gland, resulting in various metabolic disturbances.
  • The clinical presentation of fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, dry skin, coarse hair, puffiness around the eyes (periorbital edema), and hoarseness of voice are consistent with hypothyroidism.

Reference: Harrison’s Textbook of Internal Medicine, 18th Edition, Chapter No:18, Page Number-111.

questions.text: The following is the ECG of a patient who presented with acute onset breathlessness to the emergency. What is the confirmatory test for the diagnosis of the patient ?
questions.solution: Electrical alternans is recognized by alternating amplitude of the QRS complexes in any or all leads. Electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia is a highly specific sign of pericardial effusion, usually with cardiac tamponade, but it is only modestly sensitive. As a result, its absence does not exclude cardiac tamponade. It is thought that the alternating amplitude is the result of a pendulum motion of the heart as it "swings" from beat to beat within the pericardial fluid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male has had a fever for the past one week with abdominal distension and loss of appetite. He has not responded to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative, but the RK39 dipstick test is positive. Which of the following drugs can be used in the above patient?
questions.solution:
Leishmaniasis

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala azar) -L. donovani

a) Oriental sore -L. tropica

b) Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis (Espundia) -L. brasiliensis

Amphotericin B has excellent cure rate (~100%) at a dose of 0.75-1 mg/kg for 15-20 daily or alternate days intravenous infusions, however, most of the patients experience infusion reactions– eg, fever, chills, and thrombophlebitis–and occasionally serious toxicity–eg, hypokalemia, nephrotoxicity, myocarditis, and even death. These adverse effects necessitate close monitoring and hospitalization and ultimately increase the cost of the therapy.

In lipid formulations of amphotericin B, deoxycholate is replaced with other lipids leading to less exposure of the free drug to the organs. These formulations are based on the concept of targeted drug delivery to macrophages in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow: the cells and organs affected in VL. Thus, the tolerance is greatly improved and adverse effects including hypokalemia and nephrotoxicity are greatly reduced.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number-329.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?
questions.solution:
FEATURES OF MYOPIA

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of elbow dislocation?
questions.solution:
Complications of elbow dislocation are common and may be divided into early and late :-

  1. Early complications (Vascular injury) - Brachial artery may be injured. It may result in compartment syndrome and Volkmann's ischemic contracture.
  2. Late complications:-
    • Median nerve injury
    • Myositis ossificans
    • Recurrent dislocations

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-200.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman has had an ill-defined lump in her left breast for 8 months. On examination, a 4x4 cm sized, firm, non-tender ill-defined mass is felt in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Overlying skin, nipple and lymph nodes are normal. The lesion is biopsied, histopathology image of which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most phyllodes tumours present in the sixth decade, 10 to 20 years later than the peak age for fibroadenoma. Most phyllodes tumours are detected as palpable masses. As seen in image, microscopically, compared to a fibroadenoma, there is increased stromal cellularity and overgrowth, giving rise to the typical leaf-like architecture.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 1062-1063.

questions.text: A term infant is born limp, and gets intubated in the labor room. Baby is ventilated, and put on SIMV mode of ventilation. His x-ray is as follows. Which among the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The X ray is suggestive of bowel loops in the chest with shift of cardiac shadow on right. These are characteristic changes in CDH.
  • The child will present at birth with progressive respiratory distress needing respiratory support. Auscultation will confirm the bowel sounds in the chest with a shift of cardiac sounds on the right.
  • Due to shift of abdominal content in the chest, abdomen might be scaphoid.

 Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-863.

questions.text: A 29-year-old medical student was brought to pulmonologist with complaints of shortness of breath, and was given a prescription for asthma to which the physician states that it has a very high therapeutic index. Which of the statements best characterizes the drug with respect to its therapeutic index?
questions.solution:
An agent with a high therapeutic index means the toxic dose is very much higher than the therapeutic dose, and it is less likely to produce toxic effects at therapeutic levels.

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is particularly useful in the following situations:

  1. Drugs with low safety margin, e.g. - digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycoside antibiotics, lithium, tricyclic antidepressants.
  2. If individual variations are large, e.g. - antidepressants, lithium.
  3. Potentially toxic drugs used in the presence of renal failure, e.g. - aminoglycoside antibiotics, vancomycin.
  4. In case of poisoning.
  5. In case of failure of response without any apparent reason, e.g. - antimicrobials.
  6. To check patient compliance, e.g. - psychopharmacological agents.

Monitoring of plasma concentration is of no value for

  1. Drugs whose response is easily measurable, e.g. - antihypertensives, hypoglycemics, diuretics, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anaesthetics.
  2. Drugs activated in the body, e.g. - levodopa.
  3. 'Hit and run drugs' (whose effect lasts much longer than the drug itself), e.g.-reserpine, guanethidine, MAO inhibitors, omeprazole.
  4. Drugs with irreversible action, e.g. - organophosphate anticholinesterases, phenoxybenzamine.
  • Mnemonic

TDM is required for - (A Drug Possessing Low Therapeutic Index)

Aminoglycosides

Digitalis

Phenytoin

Lithium

TCAs

Immunomodulators

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-42.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman complained to the doctors of nausea and vomiting while travelling by bus. Which of the following nuclei will transmit impulses to the chemoreceptor trigger zone ?
questions.solution:
Above condition states motion sickness. Motion stimulates receptors in the vestibular labyrinth of the inner ear and from here impulses are transmitted mainly by the brainstem "vestibular nuclei " into the cerebellum and then to the chemoreceptor trigger zone and finally to the vomiting center causing vomiting.

Reference: Guyton's Textbook of Medical Physiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-478.

questions.text: Porter's tip hand is characteristic of which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
Erb’s paralysis:

  • Site of injury: Region of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (Erb’s point).
  • Six nerves meet here. Injury to the upper trunk causes Erb’s paralysis.
  • Causes of injury: Undue separation of the head from the shoulder, which is commonly encountered in the following.
    • Birth injury/difficult childbirth
    • Fall on the shoulder
    • During anaesthesia.
  • Nerve roots involved: Mainly C5 and partly C6.
  • Muscles paralysed: Mainly biceps brachii, deltoid, brachialis and brachioradialis.
  • Partly supraspinatus, infraspinatus and supinator.
  • Deformity and position of the limb:
  • Arm: Hangs by the side; it is adducted and medially rotated.
  • Forearm: Extended and pronated.
  • Known as ‘policeman’s tip hand or waiter’s tip hand or ‘porter’s tip hand’.
  • Disability: The following movements are lost.
  • Abduction and lateral rotation of the arm at shoulder joint.
  • Flexion and supination of the forearm.
  • Biceps and supinator jerks are lost.
  • Sensations are lost over a small area over the lower part of the deltoid.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page No 62, 63.

questions.text: Which cardiovascular change is not physiological in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Normal findings in CVS during pregnancy:

  • Pulse rate increases
  • Diastolic B.P decreases
  • First heart sound is prominent and split
  • Second heart sound-normal
  • Third heart sound–normally not heard but in pregnancy it is prominent
  • Murmurs-ejection systolic murmur heard normally in aortic or pulmonary area at 10–12 weeks due to expanded intravenous volume.
  • Continuous murmur heard normally over the tricuspid area in left 2–3rd intercostal space.
  • Apex beat is heard in the fourth ICS, 2.5 cms left to the midclavicular line.
  • Slight cardiomegaly
  • Ecg- left axis deviation

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in -
questions.solution:
Reciprocal or Paradoxical undressing:

  • This is a strange condition seen in accidental hypothermia, particularly in old persons.
  • In this, people take off some or all of their clothing.
  • The cause of the condition is not known.
  • It may be due to prolonged exposure to severe cold producing paralysis of the thermal regulatory mechanism (once the body temperature has fallen below about 30°C).
  • This results in failure of vasoconstriction of arterioles of the skin, which results in a flow of blood from the core of the body (Reflex vasodilation), thus giving an exaggerated sensation of warmth.
  • Terminal hallucinations occur.
  • Because of the great discomfort (as he feels hot), the person may undress himself.
  • In such cases, there may be suspicion of sexual offence.

Other associated features include:

  • Bruises and scratches of the knees, shanks, and upper limbs caused by late-phase attempts at crawling.
  • The hide-and-die phenomenon in some cas

Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon characterising some fatal hypothermia cases. The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

Terminal burrowing behavior (“Hide and Die” Syndrome) -

In very rare cases of hypothermia deaths, the disoriented, dying, hypothermia victim, who while attempting to protect himself from the cold, may hide himself in corners, in cupboards ,under piles, furniture or household goods. More commonly a naked or partly clothed old person is found amid a scene of utter confusion with furniture pulled over and drawers and cupboards emptied out, but the disturbance is at a low level and the tops of tables, etc, are not disturbed. This may lead to suspicion of homicide and robbery. Outdoors, he may attempt to burrow into snow, bush, or other constituents of the environment.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-243.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy presents with recurrent episodes of profuse epistaxis. A reddish nasal mass is seen filling the nasal cavity. Which investigation should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Angiofibroma is a highly vascular tumor and its blood vessels lack elastic tissue and muscle fibers, and hence, cannot contract. So, biopsy of the tumor results in massive hemorrhage and should be avoided.

CECT is now the investigation of choice for angiofibroma - It shows the extent of the tumour, bony destruction or displacements.

Antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomic of angiofibroma – It is the anterior displacement of posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (red arrow).

Carotid angiography shows the extent of tumours, its vascularity and feeding vessels which mostly come from the external carotid system.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is complementary to CT scans and shows any soft tissue extensions.

Reference – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number– 292. Scott Brown’s Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page Number-1266.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient, who is a known case of mycosis fungoides, develops skin lesions on the neck. On examination, there were findings of poikiloderma. Which of the following is not included in the triad of poikiloderma?
questions.solution:
• The triad of poikiloderma includes skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and pigmentary changes. Poikiloderma is often associated with conditions like mycosis fungoides, a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Skin hypertrophy is not a characteristic feature of poikiloderma.

Reference: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th Edition, Page Number-512.

questions.text: Minimum antenatal visits as per MCH is:
questions.solution:
The minimum antenatal visits recommended by the Maternal and Child Health (MCH) guidelines is option D: 4 visits.

Option D: 4 visits

  • The MCH guidelines typically recommends a minimum of 4 antenatal visits during a pregnancy. These visits are spaced out across the pregnancy timeline to monitor the health of both the mother and the developing baby.
  • These visits allow healthcare providers to conduct essential screenings, assessments, and interventions to ensure the well-being of both the mother and the baby throughout the pregnancy.
  • The visits typically occur during key gestational periods, such as the first trimester, second trimester, early third trimester, and late third trimester, to address specific needs and concerns at each stage.

Why the other options are not correct:

Option A: 1 visit:

  • Having only one antenatal visit during pregnancy is inadequate for monitoring the health and progress of the pregnancy.
  • With only one visit, healthcare providers would have limited opportunities to detect any potential complications or issues that may arise during the course of the pregnancy.
  • Regular monitoring through multiple visits allows for early detection and management of any pregnancy-related complications, reducing the risk of adverse outcomes for both the mother and the baby.

 Option B: 2 visits

  • While having two antenatal visits is better than just one, it may still not provide sufficient monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy.
  • With only two visits, there may be gaps in care, and certain important screenings or assessments may be missed.
  • Additional visits are necessary to address the various stages and needs of pregnancy comprehensively.

Option C: 3 visits:

  • Three antenatal visits offer more opportunities for monitoring and intervention compared to one or two visits.
  • However, it may still not be enough to adequately address all the necessary screenings, assessments, and interventions required during pregnancy.
  • Four visits are typically recommended to ensure comprehensive care and timely detection of any potential issues.

In summary, while the number of antenatal visits may vary based on individual circumstances and risk factors, the MCH guidelines generally recommend a minimum of 4 visits to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy. This approach allows healthcare providers to detect and address any potential complications early, optimising outcomes for both the mother and the baby.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the joints of the extremities. Examination of the synovial fluid extracted from the big toe reveals the presence of urate crystals and confirms the diagnosis of arthritis. A drug was prescribed which relieves symptoms via mechanism of competitive and suicidal inhibition. Identify the drug from the options given below.
questions.solution:
Treatment Policies in Gout:

  1. Reduce dietary purine intake and restrict alcohol.
  2. Increase renal excretion of urate by uricosuric drugs, which decrease the reabsorption of uric acid from kidney tubules, e.g. probenecid.
  3. Reduce urate production by allopurinol, an analogue of hypoxanthine. Allopurinol is a competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase thereby decreasing the formation of uric acid. Xanthine and hypoxanthine are more soluble and so are excreted more easily. Xanthine oxidase converts allopurinol to alloxanthine. It is a more effective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase. This is a good example of ‘suicide inhibition’.
  4. Colchicine, an anti-inflammatory agent is very useful to arrest the arthritis in gout.

Reference: Lippincott’s Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Chapter No: 22, Page Number-299.

questions.text:
40 year old female presented with symmetrical polyarthritis and also with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which is correct about the treatment and findings?
a. NSAIDS improve symptoms and have disease modifying activity
b. Absence of erosion on X-ray rules out diagnosis
c. Raised ESR and CRP
d. HLA DR4 is related to prognosis
questions.solution:
Joint imaging is a valuable tool not only for diagnosing RA but also for tracking progression of any joint damage. Plain x-ray is the most common imaging modality. Peri-articular osteopenia is the earliest X-ray finding. Erosions appear only later.

NSAIDs though improve symptoms, but does not have disease modifying activity.

Maternal infection acquired after 6 months has high risk of transmission

questions.text: All the following statements about toxoplasmosis are true except:
questions.solution:
The freshly passed oocyst is not infectious. It becomes infectious only after development in soil or water for a few days.

Infective forms are;

  1. a) Sporulated oocyst from contaminated soil.
  2. b) Tissue cyst containing bradyzoites in undercooked pork, beef or meat.

80-90% of immunocompetent persons with toxoplasma infection are asymptomatic.

The most common manifestation is cervical lymphadenopathy.

Transmission of T. gondii:

  1. Ingestion of sporulated oocyst (Sporocyst) or tissue cyst containing bradyzoites (most common) → oral route.
  2. Blood transfusion.
  3. Kidney or heart transplant.
  4. Transplacental transmission.

Transmission of Toxoplasma infection in pregnancy

  • Congenital infections develop only when the non-immunised mother develops infection during pregnancy or less than 6 months before pregnancy.
  • The incidence of transplacental infection is lowest in the first trimester but the disease in neonates is most severe.
  • The incidence of transplacental infection is highest in the third trimester (after 6 months) but the infant is not severely affected.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number-469.

questions.text: Muscles responsible for accommodation are innervated by nerves passing through which structure?
questions.solution:
• The muscles responsible for accommodation are innervated by nerves passing through the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. Accommodation is the process by which the eye changes its optical power to maintain a clear image of an object as its distance from the observer varies.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page Number-35

questions.text: The image given is the anteroposterior clavicle radiograph of a 40-year-old cyclist who sustained an injury after crashing during a race. Nonsurgical treatment will most likely lead to which positive outcome?
questions.solution:
Nonsurgical treatment of widely displaced clavicle fractures in young, active patients is increasingly associated with lower union and patient satisfaction rates and slower return to activities. The benefit of nonsurgical treatment is that there is no need for hardware removal, which frequently is necessary following clavicle fracture repair.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number 35-40.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with symptoms of fatigue, fever, myalgia, and neck pain for 1 week. Biopsy is performed, microscopic image of which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: De Quervain's Thyroiditis (Granulomatous thyroiditis) is triggered by a viral infection. The majority of patients have a history of an upper respiratory infection just before the onset of thyroiditis. It is the most common cause of thyroid pain. Microscopic examination shows inflammatory infiltrate composed of multinucleated giant cells, foamy histiocytes, epithelioid histiocytes, neutrophils, lymphocytes and plasma cells.

Option A: Subacute Thyroiditis, referred to as painless thyroiditis, is a presumed autoimmune disease. Most patients have circulating anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies or a family history of other autoimmune disorders. Microscopic examination reveals lymphocytic infiltration with large germinal centers within the thyroid parenchyma and patchy disruption and collapse of thyroid follicles.

Option C: Hashimoto thyroiditis is painless enlargement of the thyroid, usually associated with some degree of hypothyroidism, in a middle-aged woman. The thyroid parenchyma contains a dense lymphocytic infiltrate with germinal centers. Residual thyroid follicles lined by deeply eosinophilic Hurthle cells are seen.

Option D: Riedel Thyroiditis clinically simulates a thyroid carcinoma with hard and fixed thyroid mass. It may be associated with fibrosis in other sites in the body, such as the retroperitoneum. Microscopic examination reveals no normal lobular pattern. Follicles are obliterated or compressed by extensive dense fibrous tissue, which also infiltrates adjacent skeletal muscle. Patchy lymphocytes (B & T cells), plasma cells and eosinophils are seen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 1078-1081.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with rashes in the diaper area after using a diaper for 12 hours. All the following are first-line treatment of diaper dermatitis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• If diaper dermatitis persists after these conservative measures or if the classic satellite lesions of candida are present, treatment with an antifungal can decrease the inflammation.
  • If antifungal treatment is mentioned as an exception, it could be because not all cases of diaper dermatitis are caused by fungal infections, and antifungal treatment may not be necessary in every case. The first-line approach usually involves the measures mentioned in other options and antifungal treatment may be added if there is a specific indication of a fungal infection.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-2608.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient recently diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis was started on a therapy with a newer biological agent which is acting by competing with CD28 to prevent full T-cell activation. Which amongst the following agents for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) competes with CD28 to prevent full T-cell activation?
questions.solution:
Abatacept is a costimulation modulator that competes with CD28 to prevent its binding on CD80/CD86 protein, resulting in reduced T-cell activation.

Golimumab and adalimumab are both TNF-α inhibitors, and sarilumab is an IL-6 inhibitor.

Abatacept- It is a recombinant fusion protein which combines a part of the Fc domain of human IgG with the extracellular domain of T-cell inhibitory receptor CTLA4.

By binding to CD80 and CD86 molecules, it prevents the 2nd signal for costimulation of T-cells. Beneficial response occurs in many RA patients who are refractory to a combination of Mtx + a TNFα antagonist.

Abatacept is approved for use in moderate-severe active RA, not responding to Mtx.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-230.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old female complained of vertigo, intermittent weakness of the right lower limb for 2 days, and severe headache. On physical examination, plethoric face and conjunctival injection, over all dusky cyanotic complexion were observed.
Pulse-60 BPM, regular rate and rhythm.
BP-250/110 mm Hg.
RBC count: 8 million/mm3, Hematocrit: 65%
WBC: 20,000/microLT
Platelets: 6,00,000/microLT.
Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Given clinical picture is of Polycythemia Vera in which there is genetic aberration in hemocytoblast cells. In PCV, the viscosity of blood is greatly increased, blood vessels are plugged by viscous blood. It is a myeloproliferative disorder associated with JAK2-V617F mutation.

Treatment mainly remains phlebotomy, one unit of blood is removed weekly until the hematocrit is less than 45%. Low dose aspirin to reduce the risk of thrombosis. Other drugs that can be used are Ruxolitinib, Hydroxyurea and pegylated Alpha-2 interferon.

Reference: Guyton's Textbook of Medical Physiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-428.

questions.text: Following x ray is associated with which congenital urogenital condition?
questions.solution:
The X ray shows separation of the pubic bones with non-united pubic symphysis. This is most likely a case of ectopia vesicae (bladder exstrophy).

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital disorder in which the bladder is exposed on the outside of the abdomen due to a defect in the anterior abdominal wall.

  • Male to female ratio is 4:1.
  • It is associated with:
    • Epispadias
    • Increased risk of bladder cancer
    • Urinary incontinence
    • In males - bilateral inguinal hernia, undescended testis.
    • In females - bifid clitoris, wide open pelvis (duck gait), wide labia.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 83, Page Number-1492.

questions.text: Dorsiflexion is brought by all the following muscles EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Dorsiflexion is the movement that brings the top of the foot toward the shin. The muscles responsible for dorsiflexion are primarily located in the anterior compartment of the leg. Let's examine the options:

  1. Tibialis Anterior: This muscle is a prime mover in dorsiflexion. It runs along the front of the leg and is responsible for lifting the foot upward.
  2. Extensor digitorum longus: This muscle also contributes to dorsiflexion. It extends the toes and assists in lifting the foot.
  3. Extensor hallucis longus: This muscle is involved in dorsiflexion and extends the big toe.
  4. Peroneus longus: This muscle is not a primary dorsiflexor. It is located on the lateral side of the leg and is involved in eversion (moving the sole of the foot outward) and plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward).

So, the correct answer is d. Peroneus longus. It is not a muscle primarily responsible for dorsiflexion.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number-178.

questions.text: Recurrent spontaneous abortions are seen in all except:
questions.solution:
• Recurrent spontaneous abortions are not commonly associated with TORCH infections.
  • TORCH infections include toxoplasmosis, other (syphilis, varicella-zoster, parvovirus B19), rubella, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and herpes simplex virus(HSV). While infections can contribute to spontaneous abortions, they are not a cause of recurrent spontaneous abortions.

choices.text: Involves superficial layers of the skin
Caused by contact with a rough surface
Direction of application of force can be determined by examining the wound

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding abrasions.
questions.solution:
An abrasion is the destruction of the skin, which involves only superficial layers of skin, ie.., only epidermis.

It is a two-dimensional injury - only length and breadth. It bleeds less and does not form scars after healing.

A grazed abrasion is produced, when a broad area of the skin is scraped against a broad rough surface.

A scratch can be produced by the tip of a knife or any pointed object. Direction can be made out by the heaped-up epithelium at the end.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by K.S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-134.

questions.text: A singer underwent thyroid surgery 1 month ago. Her recovery has been satisfactory except that she is unable to sing higher notes now. What is the possible nerve injury which could have happened during the thyroid surgery of this patient?
questions.solution:
Paralysis of the superior laryngeal nerve causes paralysis of cricothyroid muscle, and ipsilateral anaesthesia of the larynx above the vocal cords.

Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cords, which is supplied by the external branch of SLN. Paralysis of this muscle leads to bowing down of vocal cords and hence, loss of pitch of the voice with decreased ability to sing.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number-350.

questions.text: A 10 year old female patient presents with a history of severe sunburn after only a few minutes in the sun. On examination, freckles, dry skin and skin pigmentation is noted. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Xeroderma pigmentosum is a rare autosomal recessive genodermatosis that results due to mutations in the nucleotide excision repair. The condition is characterized by severe photosensitivity, skin pigmentary changes, malignant tumor development, and occasionally progressive neurologic degeneration.
  • Areas exposed to the sun such as the face show freckling.
  • Continued sun exposure will lead to the second stage, which is characterized by: Poikiloderma (Skin atrophy, Telangiectasia, Mottled hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation)

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page Number-653.

choices.text: Give a dose of TT & explain to her that it will not protect the newborn & she should take the second dose after 4 weeks even if she delivers in the meantime.
Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy.
Given one dose of TT, explain it will not be useful for this pregnancy.
Give anti-tetanus immunoglobulin along with the TT vaccine.

questions.text: A 37 weeks pregnant woman attends an antenatal clinic at a PHC. She has not had any antenatal care till now. The best approach here regarding TT immunization would be:
questions.solution:
The best approach regarding TT immunization for a 37-week pregnant woman attending an antenatal clinic at a Primary Health Centre (PHC) who has not had any antenatal care till now would be option A: Give a dose of TT and explain to her that it will not protect the newborn and she should take the second dose after 4 weeks even if she delivers in the meantime.

  • This option is the best approach because administering Tetanus Toxoid (TT) vaccine at this stage of pregnancy can provide some level of protection against tetanus for the mother during delivery and for the newborn.
  • Even though the full course of TT vaccination requires multiple doses for optimal protection, giving at least one dose of TT at this late stage of pregnancy can still offer some benefit.
  • By explaining to the woman that this dose will not fully protect the newborn and advising her to take the second dose after 4 weeks regardless of whether she delivers in the meantime, healthcare providers can ensure that she receives appropriate follow-up care for tetanus prevention.

Why the other options are not correct:

Option B: Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy:

  • This option is not recommended because administering TT vaccine, even at this late stage, can still provide some level of protection against tetanus for the mother during delivery.
  • While one dose may not fully protect the newborn, it can still offer some benefit to the mother, and it sets the stage for follow-up vaccination after delivery.

Option C: Give one dose of TT, explain it will not be useful for this pregnancy:

  • Simply giving the TT vaccine without providing proper information about its limitations and follow-up care may lead to confusion or misunderstanding on the part of the pregnant woman.
  • It is essential to educate the woman about the purpose and timing of TT vaccination to ensure that she understands the importance of follow-up care.

Option D: Give anti-tetanus immunoglobulin along with the TT vaccine:

  • Administering anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is not typically indicated for routine antenatal care unless there is a specific indication, such as a tetanus-prone wound or a history of incomplete or inadequate TT vaccination.
  • Using immunoglobulin alongside TT vaccine in this scenario would not be appropriate without a specific indication for its use.

In summary, option A is the best approach because it provides some level of protection against tetanus for the mother and sets the stage for follow-up vaccination after delivery, while also ensuring that the woman receives proper information about the limitations of the vaccine and the need for additional doses.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her physician with muscle weakness, fatigue, and exercise intolerance. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show elevated levels of lactate and alanine, along with hypoglycemia. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Von Gierke disease (type I glycogen storage disease):

  • Defect: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to glycogen storage diseases.
  • Biochemical alteration:
    • This enzyme is responsible for the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose, a crucial step in both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
    • In its absence, glucose-6-phosphate accumulates, leading to impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, resulting in hypoglycemia.
    • Elevated lactate and alanine levels are indicative of increased anaerobic glycolysis and conversion of pyruvate to lactate and alanine, respectively, due to the inability to generate glucose from glucose-6-phosphate.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Recurrent episode of hypoglycemia
    • Easy bruising and nosebleeds
    • Fatigue
    • Irritability
    • Delayed puberty
    • Enlarged liver
    • Gout
    • Stunted growth or failure to grow
  • Other Options:
    • Hexokinase deficiency would lead to impaired glucose phosphorylation and would not typically present with hepatomegaly.
    • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is associated with removal of free radicals by producing NADPH. Hence, its deficiency is associated with haemolytic anemia, not hepatomegaly and exercise intolerance.
    • Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) deficiency would impair glycolytic flux and lead to exercise intolerance but is not associated with hepatomegaly or hypoglycemia.
  • Glycogen Storage Disorder:
    • von Gierke's disease
    • Pompe's disease.
    • Cori's disease
    • Anderson's disease
    • McArdle's disease
    • Hers disease
    • Tay Sach's Disease
  • Mnemonic: Viagra Pills Cause A Massive Hardon and Tired
  • For the enzymes:
  • Glycogen storage disease type 1 mnemonic:
    Geirke - Glucose 6 phosphatase. Both have a G!
  • Glycogen storage disease type 3 and 4 mnemonic:
    Mnemonic for Anderson's and Cori's is, "ABCD"
    A-B(ranching): Anderson's - Branching enzyme.
    C-D(ebranching): Cori's - Debranching enzyme.
  • Glycogen storage disease type 5 mnemonic:
    Muscle phosphorylase     forMcArdle's. Both have a M in the name!
  • Glycogen storage disease type 6 mnemonic:
    So Liver phosphorylase is affected in Hers disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:18, Page Number-174.

questions.text: A patient presented with bitemporal hemianopia. On imaging it is found that an artery aneurysm is pressing on optic chiasm. What is the likely artery involved?
questions.solution: Bitemporal hemianopia can be caused by a large intracranial aneurysm of the ACoA.

questions.text: A child from Bihar presents to the OPD with fever. Blood examination shows sheathed microfilariae with 2 spaced nuclei up to tail tip. Which is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
'Sheathed microfilariae with nuclei upto the tip' is a feature of B. Malayi.

Note: Loa-Loa also has sheathed microfilaria with nuclei up to tail tip, but it is uncommon in India and it does not cause fever. It causes subcutaneous swelling-calabar swelling or fugitive swelling.

choices.text: Autorefraction with the use of accommodative control

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came for evaluation for a recent onset of exotropia. What step should be considered next?
questions.solution:
• In a case of a 5-year-old child with exotropia, the next step should be cycloplegic refraction. Cycloplegic refraction is crucial in young children and patients with strabismus, as it helps determine the objective refractive error by relaxing accommodation.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page Number 726, 733.

questions.text: A patient with tibial fracture put on a cast presented to the casualty with complaints of pain of the injured limb. His cast was cut and on examination, there was pain on passive flexion of the limb, loss of sensation in the first web space and posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulses were present. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Based on the given history, the patient is most likely suffering from compartment syndrome.

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

  • It is usually seen in cases where a tight cast is applied to a limb following fracture, resulting in raised pressure inside the cast.
  • This can lead to decreased blood supply to the affected limb/part.
  • Ischemia leads to inflammation of the muscles causing them to swell up inside the fascial compartment and compress the supplying blood vessels (veins and arteries) leading to further ischemia.

CLINICAL FEATURES:

  • Pain on passive stretching
  • Pallor
  • Paresthesia
  • Paralysis
  • Pulselessness

DIAGNOSIS

  • The intra - compartmental pressure is measured.
  • > 30 mm Hg is diagnostic of compartment syndrome.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-2405.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number 332-334.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male complains of forgetfulness. His relatives also complain of gradual memory loss for a long time. Later, he develops problems in simple mathematical calculations. A few months later, he develops incontinence and has a problem in walking. He later died of pneumonia. On autopsy, histology of his brain showed neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Which is the predominant protein in these plaques?
questions.solution:
Patient is suffering from Alzheimer disease. Initial symptoms are forgetfulness and other memory disturbances; with progression, other symptoms emerge, including language deficits, loss of mathematical skills, and loss of learned motor skills. In the final stages, affected individuals may become incontinent, mute, and unable to walk; intercurrent disease, often pneumonia, is usually the terminal event.

Neuritic plaques are focal, spherical collections of dilated, tortuous, axonal or dendritic processes (dystrophic neurites) often around a central amyloid core, which may be surrounded by a clear halo.

The amyloid core, which can be stained by Congo red or a beta amyloid immunostain, contains several abnormal proteins. The dominant component of the amyloid plaque core is Aβ, a peptide derived by proteolytic cleavage of APP; other proteins, including components of the complement cascade, proinflammatory cytokines, α1-antichymotrypsin, and apolipoproteins, are present in lesser abundance.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-1278.

choices.text: It is a source of pleasure
It is a sign of insecurity
It can cause malocclusion of teeth
It must be vigorously treated in the first year

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about thumb sucking?
questions.solution:
• Thumb sucking is common in infancy and in as many as 25% of children aged 2 years, and 15% of children aged 5 years. Thumb sucking beyond 5 years may be associated with sequelae (paronychia, anterior open bite).
  • Like other rhythmic patterns of behaviour, thumb sucking is self-soothing.
  • Basic behavioural management, including encouraging parents to ignore thumb sucking and instead focus on praising the child for substitute behaviours, is often an effective treatment. Simple reminders and reinforcers, such as giving the child a sticker (or other rewards) for each block of time that he or she does not suck the thumb can also be considered.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-144.

questions.text: A 59 year old male was brought to the emergency department with abnormal heart rhythm. Later, laboratory tests revealed his potassium level to be 6.5 meq/L suggesting hyperkalemia. Which amongst the following is least useful in the treatment of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
β2-Agonists, most commonly albuterol, are effective but underused agents for the acute management of hyperkalemia.

Albuterol and insulin with glucose have an additive effect on plasma K+ concentration; however, ~20% of patients with ESRD are resistant to the effect of β2-agonists; hence, these drugs should not be used without insulin.

Hyperglycemia is a side effect, along with tachycardia. β2-Agonists should be used with caution in hyperkalemic patients with known cardiac disease.

Hemodialysis is the most effective and reliable method to reduce plasma K+ concentration; peritoneal dialysis is considerably less effective.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page Number-355.

questions.text:
Chronaxie is the measure of excitability of the tissue. Arrange the chronaxie in the correct order, from highest to lowest.
(a) Myelinated Nerve
(b) Skeletal Muscle
(c) Smooth Muscle
(d) Unmyelinated Nerve
(e) Cardiac Muscle
questions.solution:
Chronaxie is the measure of excitability of the tissue. It is defined as the time taken to excite when double the rheobase stimulus is applied.

Rheobase is defined as the minimum strength of stimulus that can excite a tissue.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page Number 85-96.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for prostatectomy in BPH?
questions.solution:
Residual urine of 200ml or more is an indication.

Strong indications for prostatectomy include:

  • Acute retention in fit men with no other cause for retention (drugs, constipation, recent operation).
  • Chronic retention and renal impairment;
    • Residual urine of 200mL or more
    • Raised blood urea
    • Hydroureter or hydronephrosis
    • Uraemic manifestations
  • Complications of bladder outflow obstruction - stone, infection and diverticulum.
  • Haemorrhage - occasionally, venous bleeding from a ruptured vein overlying the prostate will require prostatectomy to be performed.
  • Elective prostatectomy for severe symptoms-
    • Increasing difficulty in micturition, with considerable frequency in the day and night.
    • Delay in starting and a poor stream.

Acute retention of urine is sometimes the first symptom of BOO. Chronic retention in patients in whom the residual volume is >250 mL or so, the tension in the bladder wall increases owing to the combination of a large volume of residual urine and increased resting and filling bladder pressures (a condition known as high-pressure chronic retention).

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-1524.

questions.text: Protrusion of meninges and spinal cord with dilated central canal from spina bifida results in the formation of a cystic swelling filled with cerebrospinal fluid. This condition is known as:
questions.solution:
Spina bifida:

  • The two halves of the neural arch may fail to fuse leaving a gap in the midline.
  • This is called spina bifida.
  • Meninges and spinal cord may herniate out through the gap.
  • Protrusion of meninges alone results in the formation of a cystic swelling filled with cerebrospinal fluid. This swelling is called meningocele.
  • When the spinal cord is also present in the swelling the condition is called meningomyelocele.
  • The central canal of the herniated part of the cord may be dilated. This condition is called syringomyelocele.
  • At times, the spinal cord may itself be open posteriorly. The condition is then called myelocoele.
  • Sometimes a spina bifida is present, but there is no protrusion through it so that there is no swelling on the surface, but a tuft of hair may be present at the site of defect. This is referred to as spina bifida occulta.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page Number-222.

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital abnormality of the uterus?
questions.solution: Unicornuate uterus accounts for 1-2% of all utero vaginal anomalies and is often associated with a poor reproductive performance, while bicornuate uterus is present in 25% of cases, Septate uterus is most common and is associated with higher incidence of pregnancy wastage, about 25% incidence of spontaneous first trimester abortions, 6% second trimester abortions.

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On examination, the Kevorkian sign is noticed. What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
• The Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels. It lasts for about 1 hour.
  • It is characterised by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death
  • It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-112.

questions.text: A 33 year old female patient suddenly developed aphonia. Her laryngeal endoscopy shows immobile cords as shown in the picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Both the vocal cords are lying immobile in intermediate or cadaveric position. There is no adduction.

Hence, the diagnosis is bilateral adductor palsy.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number-349.

questions.text: A 27 year old female patient presents with copious, watery, foul smelling vaginal discharge. Which of the following will not be included in the diagnostic criteria?
questions.solution:
Bacterial Vaginosis : Amsel's Criteria

  1. Vaginal Discharge
  2. Vaginal pH > 4.5
  3. Whiff Test - Ammonical fishy odor
  4. Clue cells >20%

choices.text: Undertaken among persons who have very early symptoms of a diseases.
Undertaken by means of tests which can be rapidly applied.
Undertaken to sort out those who probably have the disease from those who do not have.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component in the concept of screening?
questions.solution:
(b) Undertaken among persons who have very early symptoms of a disease: This option suggests that screening is conducted among individuals who already have early symptoms of a disease. However, screening is typically performed on asymptomatic individuals or those who have risk factors for a particular condition but have not yet developed symptoms. The goal is to identify diseases before symptoms manifest, enabling early intervention and improved prognosis. Therefore, screening is not usually undertaken among individuals with early symptoms of a disease.

Why other options are not correct:

(a) Search for unrecognised diseases: Screening is primarily aimed at detecting diseases or risk factors in individuals who do not exhibit symptoms. By identifying diseases at an early stage, interventions can be initiated to prevent or mitigate the progression of the disease, leading to better health outcomes. Therefore, searching for unrecognized diseases is a key component of screening.

(c) Undertaken by means of tests which can be rapidly applied: One of the practical considerations in screening is the ability to administer tests quickly and efficiently to a large population. Rapid applicability of tests allows for timely identification of individuals who may require further evaluation or intervention. Therefore, utilizing tests that can be rapidly applied is an important aspect of screening.

(d) Undertaken to sort out those who probably have the disease from those who do not have: Screening tests are designed to distinguish between individuals who are likely to have the disease (screen-positive) and those who are unlikely to have the disease (screen-negative). By identifying individuals who probably have the disease, screening facilitates the referral of these individuals for further diagnostic evaluation and appropriate management. Similarly, identifying individuals who probably do not have the disease helps to avoid unnecessary diagnostic procedures and reduce healthcare costs. Therefore, sorting individuals based on their likelihood of having the disease is a fundamental objective of screening.

In summary, while options (a), (c), and (d) align with the principles of screening, option (b) is not consistent with the concept of screening as it suggests testing individuals who already have early symptoms of a disease, which is typically not the case in screening programs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a history of joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and easy bruising. Upon further investigation, it is found that she has a deficiency in an enzyme responsible for the synthesis of a specific glycosaminoglycan. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms described are characteristic of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), specifically the hypermobility type (EDS type III) or the classical type (EDS type I or II).
  • These types of EDS are associated with defects in the synthesis of type I collagen, a major component of connective tissue.
  • Lysyl hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the post-translational modification of collagen, specifically in the hydroxylation of lysine residues, which is necessary for proper collagen cross-linking and stability.
  • Deficiency in lysyl hydroxylase activity leads to impaired collagen fibril formation, resulting in joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and easy bruising, characteristic features of EDS.
  • Arylsulfatase, α-N-acetyl glucosaminidase, and β-glucuronidase are enzymes involved in the degradation of glycosaminoglycans but are not associated with EDS.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:50, Page Number-602.

choices.text: Schedule an urgent temporal artery biopsy

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in her left eye. She reports increased fatigue over the past month and pain in her jaw muscles while chewing. On examination, she has temporal artery tenderness on the left. Her visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye and 20/400 in the left eye, with a prominent left relative afferent pupillary defect. Her left optic disc appears pallid and edematous, while her right disc is normal. She has inferior visual field loss in the left eye. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 80 mm/hr. Which of the following is the most important next step in this patient's management?
questions.solution: The clinical scenario is that of a Giant cell arteritis complicated by AION (Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy). This is a medical emergency and should be treated with parenteral steroids urgently.

questions.text: In HIV infected individuals, gram stain of the lung aspirate shows yeast-like morphology. All the following are the most likely diagnosis except____.
questions.solution:
In this question, the positive organism should fulfill the following two criteria:

  • Causes lung infection in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The organism should have a yeast-like morphology.

Among the organisms mentioned in the question, aspergillus fumigatus does not fulfill the above mentioned criterias. It causes lung infection in immunocompromised patients but it does not occur in yeast like form.

Microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus:

  • Non pigmented septate mycelium with characteristic dichotomous branching and an irregular outline.

All the other fungi mentioned in the question occur in yeast-like form.

Penicillium marneffei: It is a dimorphic fungus. It forms yeast-like cells that are often intracellular resembling histoplasmosis. It causes systemic infections in AIDS patients in Asia.

Candida tropicalis: All candida species can occur in yeast -like form. Bronchopulmonary candidiasis can occur as a rare complication of preexisting pulmonary or systemic disease.

Cryptococcus neoformans: Microscopy reveals capsulated yeasts. It can cause lung infections in AIDS patients.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number 85-87,406-407.

questions.text: A mass causing a pupillary defect and a homonymous hemianopia would most likely be found in which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• A mass affecting the optic tract can lead to homonymous hemianopia associated with contralateral hemianopic pupillary reaction (Wernicke's reaction).
  • Optic tract lesions may also be associated with contralateral third nerve paralysis and ipsilateral hemiplegia as it in close relation with corticospinal tract

questions.text: A 30-year male complains of recurrent backache and stiffness in the spinal region. Lumbar spine X ray of this patient is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Young male with low back ache along with x ray showing bamboo spine appearance is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

In women, the spine is most commonly involved. It is associated with HLA B27 [seronegative] mutation.

HLA B27 is also involved in -

P - Psoriatic arthritis

E - Enteropathic arthritis

A - Ankylosing spondylitis

R - Reitters syndrome/Reactive arthritis

S - SAPHO Syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, Osteitis)

Most commonly involves the sacroiliac joints.

CLINICAL - Decreased chest movements, low back ache, with hands, wrist & elbow spared.

CHARACTERISTIC FEATURES - Enthesitis (Inflammation of insertion of tendons & ligaments). Axial skeleton disease, 30% associated with anterior uveitis. Treated with steroids & cycloplegics. Cardiac conduction defects [ Aortic regurgitation].

Option A - In Pott's spine, there is reduction of the intervertebral disc space with a history of TB.

Option C - Psoriatic Arthritis - Pencil in cup deformity is seen in x ray.

Option D - In RA, the patient has morning stiffness and pain in mostly small joints of the hand. On X ray - swan neck deformity, Boutonniere deformity/Buttonhole deformity, Z deformity are seen.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-371.

questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are characteristically seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are laminated mineralized concretions resulting from deposition of calcium in enlarged lysosomes, and are typically present within the macrophages.

Image shows large macrophages with granular PAS-positive cytoplasm and several dense, round

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies surrounded by artifactually cleared holes in the upper middle field (arrow).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-956.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of sepsis in neonates in India?
questions.solution:
The common causes of Neonatal sepsis in India are:

  • Klebsiella
  • Staphylococcus Aureus
  • E. coli
  • Pseudomonas
  • Enterobacter
  • Coagulase negative staphylococcus
  • Acenatobacter
  • Candida

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-708.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has hypertension. A thiazide diuretic agent had been prescribed by his physician and on follow up, he was still having continued elevated blood pressure. His physician has decided to include spironolactone to his existing medicine. The inclusion of spironolactone to the thiazide diuretic is done to achieve which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
Spironolactone and eplerenone themselves lower BP slightly.

When used in conjunction with a thiazide diuretic, they prevent K+ loss and augment the antihypertensive action.

Spironolactone has hormonal side effects (gynaecomastia, impotence, menstrual irregularities).

The NICE and JNC 8 guidelines recommend adding an aldosterone antagonist to the ACE inhibitor/ARB + CCB + thiazide regimen, if the target level BP is not attained. Hyperkalemia should be watched when aldosterone antagonists are used, particularly in combination with ACE inhibitors/ARBs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-607.

questions.text: A young male patient had urethral injury after a road traffic accident. Following procedure has been performed. What is the likely procedure?
questions.solution:
(a) Percutaneous puncture of the bladder with passage of a guidewire into the bladder followed by dilatation of the track over the guidewire, thereby allowing placement of a catheter into the bladder.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-1509.

questions.text: Lymphatic drainage of the area marked by pink colour in the following image is:
questions.solution:
• Upper territory, including the greater part of the forehead, lateral halves of eyelids, conjunctiva, lateral part of the cheek and parotid area, drains into the preauricular parotid nodes.
  • Middle territory, including a strip over the median part of the forehead, external nose, upper lip, lateral part of the lower lip, medial halves of the eyelids, medial part of the cheek, and the greater part of lower jaw, drains into the submandibular nodes.
  • Lower territory, including the central part of the lower lip and the chin, drains into the submental nodes.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page Number-77.

questions.text: Spalding sign is seen after:
questions.solution: • A spalding sign, characterized by the irregular overlapping of the cranial bones, is seen about 7 days after intrauterine fetal death (IUFD). It is a radiological finding observed in cases of IUFD

choices.text: Extradural hemorrhage may be ruled out in the absence of a skull fracture
A minimum of 35 ml of blood is required to accumulate for clinical signs to appear
The most common vessel affected is middle meningeal artery
It is the least common type of traumatic brain membrane hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following statements about extradural hemorrhage is false?
questions.solution:
Extradural hemorrhages (EDH) cannot be ruled out in the absence of a skull fracture.

Most extradural hemorrhages are associated with fractures of the skull, but about 15 per cent occur in intact skulls.

They usually occur unilaterally in the parieto-temporal area, caused by the rupture of the middle meningeal artery (usually posterior branch).

It is the least common type of brain membrane bleeding.

The most common traumatic intracranial hemorrhage is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Adam suggests that a minimum volume of 35 ml is needed before clinical signs are apparent, though other writers suggest 100 ml is usually the minimum associated with fatalities.

Reference: Knight's Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Page Number 182,183.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a patient who underwent laryngectomy. Which mode of speech will he use?
questions.solution:
In the image, a laryngectomy has been performed, which means the patient's larynx (voice box) has been removed. In such cases, patients often use alternative methods to produce speech. Tracheoesophageal speech is a common method used by laryngectomy patients. It involves the surgical creation of a small opening between the trachea and the esophagus, through which air can be redirected from the lungs into the esophagus. By expelling air from the esophagus, patients can produce speech sounds and communicate.

Reference: Textbook of ENT and Head & Neck Surgery by Hazarika, 4th Edition, Page Number-541.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with painful blisters and erosions predominantly over upper body. Histopathology findings are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pemphigus Foliaceous is characterized by small, flaccid bullae with crusting and scaling. Bullae rupture, resulting in moist erosions and crusts.
  • Nikolsky's sign is positive.
  • Oral mucosa involvement is absent.

Immunopathology demonstrates IgG on surface keratinocytes, and autoantibodies are directed against Desmoglein1.

  • PV : Suprabasal split, row of tombstones
  • PF : Subcorneal split

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page Number-842.

questions.text: Usefulness of a screening test is given by:
questions.solution:
(a) Sensitivity: Sensitivity measures the ability of a screening test to correctly identify individuals who have the disease or condition (true positives) among all individuals who actually have the disease. A high sensitivity indicates that the test is effective in detecting the presence of the disease when it is truly present, minimizing false negatives. Therefore, sensitivity is crucial in determining the usefulness of a screening test because it ensures that individuals who may benefit from further diagnostic evaluation or intervention are not missed during the screening process.

Why other options are not correct:

(b) Specificity: Specificity measures the ability of a screening test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the disease or condition (true negatives) among all individuals who do not have the disease. While specificity is important in ruling out individuals who do not have the disease, it does not directly reflect the usefulness of the screening test in identifying individuals who do have the disease.

(c) Positive Predictive Value (PPV): PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive on the screening test actually have the disease. While PPV is important in assessing the likelihood of disease presence among individuals who test positive, it is influenced by both sensitivity and specificity, as well as the prevalence of the disease in the population. Therefore, PPV alone may not fully capture the usefulness of the screening test.

(d) Negative Predictive Value (NPV): NPV indicates the probability that individuals who test negative on the screening test truly do not have the disease. Similar to PPV, NPV is influenced by both sensitivity and specificity, as well as the prevalence of the disease in the population. While NPV is important in assessing the likelihood of disease absence among individuals who test negative, it does not directly reflect the usefulness of the screening test in identifying individuals who do have the disease.

In summary, sensitivity is the most appropriate measure for determining the usefulness of a screening test because it directly assesses the test's ability to identify individuals who have the disease among those who truly have the disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old vegetarian presents to the clinic with complaints of weakness, fatigue, and tingling sensations in his hands and feet. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva and glossitis. Laboratory investigations show macrocytic anemia and elevated levels of serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
• Pernicious anemia is a condition characterized by vitamin B12 deficiency, often due to impaired absorption or inadequate dietary intake.
  • Vitamin B12 is essential for the synthesis of DNA and the proper functioning of the nervous system.
  • In pernicious anemia, the lack of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 absorption in the ileum, leads to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • The symptoms described, including weakness, fatigue, tingling sensations, pale conjunctiva, and glossitis, are typical manifestations of pernicious anemia.
  • Laboratory investigations typically reveal macrocytic anemia (large red blood cells), elevated serum homocysteine, and methylmalonic acid levels due to impaired folate and methionine metabolism.
  • Iron deficiency anemia presents with microcytic (small red blood cells) and hypochromic (pale) red blood cells and does not typically involve neurological symptoms.
  • Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency leads to Beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, characterized by neurological symptoms and cardiovascular effects, but does not present with macrocytic anemia.
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to a microcytic anemia and neurological symptoms but is less commonly associated with macrocytic anemia.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:44, Page Number-544.

questions.text: A patient was admitted in the neurocritical care. On Examination, level of consciousness was assessed. With painful stimulus Eye opening and withdrawal were seen. Inappropriate words were being spoken What is the GCS ?

A patient made a self-diagnosis of an athlete's foot (tinea pedis) and began using a product advertised on the television. His condition improved, but did not resolve completely. The patient then visited a dermatologist. A skin scraping was sent to the laboratory for culture, including culture for fungi. The fungal culture yielded a slow growing colony, which produced a few small microconidia. This is consistent with isolation of a dermatophyte from which genre?
questions.solution:
Dermatophytes can be identified by their colonial appearance and microscopic morphology after growth for 2 weeks at 25°c on Sabouraud's dextrose agar.

Differential diagnosis of dermatophytes on the basis of macroconidia and microconidia;

Trichophyton- Abundant microconidia, arranged in clusters along the hyphae.

Macroconidia-Relatively scanty, elongated with blunt ends.

Microsporum

  • Single macroconidia
  • spindle shaped
  • Scanty microconidia

Epidermoplyton

  • No microconidia
  • Macroconidia in groups of 2 or 3

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number 601-603

questions.text: Which congenital disorder is microspherophakia associated with?
questions.solution:
• Microspherophakia, a condition where the lens is small and spherical, is most often associated with Weill-Marchesani syndrome.
  • It can also be linked to other diseases such as Peters anomaly, Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, Lowe syndrome, and congenital rubella.
  • Short stature, progressive joint stiffness, brachydactyly, thick skin, mild mental retardation, and cardiac anomalies

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy has had thigh pain for the past several months. He denies any history of trauma. Examination reveals a large, deeply fixed, soft-tissue mass in the thigh. Laboratory results show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and leukocytosis. A plain radiograph and MRI scan are shown in Figures 1A and 1B. Biopsy specimens are shown in Figures 1C and 1D. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ewing's sarcoma typically can occur in the diaphysis of the long bones (50% to 55%). It is often accompanied by a large soft-tissue mass. Abnormal findings are common, including a low-grade fever, an elevated ESR, and leukocytosis. The histology is consistent with a small round blue cell tumor.

The unique pathology and other findings exclude osteosarcoma. Giant cell tumor and chondrosarcoma have a different histologic appearance and typically are more metaphyseal in location. Chondrosarcoma typically, is found in older age groups, has a different histologic pattern, and rarely occurs in the midshaft of the femur.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number 287-297.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient complains of diarrhea and abdominal pain. On examination, his blood pressure is raised. 2-3 days later, he developed sudden anuria. His platelet count is 20,000/mm3, creatinine is 4.3 mg/dL, and on peripheral smear study, normoblasts and schistocytes are seen. On further workup, his ADAMTS13 levels are found to be within normal limit and stool culture is also negative with Shiga toxin test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Atypical HUS. HUS is associated with normal levels of ADAMTS13 and is initiated by several other distinct defects. "Typical" HUS is strongly associated with infectious gastroenteritis caused by Escherichia coli strain O157:H7, which elaborates a Shiga-like toxin. Normal ADAMTS13 rules out TTP. "Atypical" HUS is often associated with defects in complement factor H, membrane cofactor protein (CD46), or factor I, proteins that act to prevent excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.

Clinical Pentad of TTP includes:

  • Fever
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurological manifestations

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 665-666.
