questions.text: A 67 year old male patient was brought to the emergency room with a history of road traffic accident. He presented with pelvic fracture and head trauma. On investigation, his CT scan was suggestive of raised ICT. He was given morphine for pain relief by the attending physician, following which he immediately developed respiratory difficulty. Which of the following could be the most accurate justification for his respiratory difficulty?
questions.solution:
PRECAUTIONS AND CONTRAINDICATIONS of Morphine

Morphine is a drug of emergency, but due care has to be taken in its use.

  1. Infants and the elderly are more susceptible to the respiratory depressant action of morphine.
  2. It is dangerous in patients with respiratory insufficiency (emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, cor pulmonale); sudden deaths have occurred.
  3. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can precipitate an attack by its histamine releasing action.
  4. Head injury: Morphine is contraindicated in patients with head injury. Reasons are-
    • By retaining CO2, it increases intracranial tension which will add to that caused by head injury itself.
    • Even therapeutic doses can cause marked respiratory depression in these patients.
    • Vomiting, miosis and altered mentation produced by morphine interfere with assessment of progress in head injury cases.
  5. Hypotensive states and hypovolaemia exaggerate fall in BP due to morphine.
  6. Undiagnosed acute abdominal pain
  7. Elderly male: chances of urinary retention are high.
  8. Hypothyroidism, liver and kidney disease patients are more sensitive to morphine.
  9. Unstable personalities are able to continue with its use and become addicted.

[Moderate]

[Clinical question]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-502.

questions.text: What is the gold standard technique for diagnosis of coronary artery disease?
questions.solution:
• Selective coronary angiography provides the means of accurately diagnosing the presence and extent of CAD and remains the 'gold standard' diagnostic technique.
  • In spite of the availability of newer imaging techniques such as cardiac MRI, selective coronary angiography provides high image quality, demonstrating the extent, severity and location of coronary artery stenoses and the quality and size of the distal coronary arteries.

Any stenosis in an artery of >70% of the diameter (90% reduction of cross-sectional area) is considered 'severe'. In addition, angiography can assess ventricular function and provide the cardiac surgeon with information to determine operability, operative risk and probability of the operative result. Coronary angiography only outlines the coronary anatomy, does not demonstrate ischaemia and carries an overall complication rate of less than 1%.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-949.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is supplied by the inferior root of ansa cervicalis?
questions.solution:
Ansa cervicalis:

  • This is a thin nerve loop that lies embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath over the lower part of the larynx.
  • It supplies the infrahyoid muscles.
  • Formation: It is formed by a superior and an inferior root.
  • The superior root is the continuation of the descending branch of the hypoglossal nerve. Its fibres are derived from the first cervical nerve.
  • The inferior root or descending cervical nerve is derived from second and third cervical spinal nerves.
  • Distribution
  • Superior root: To the superior belly of the omohyoid.
  • Ansa cervicalis: To the sternohyoid, the sternothyroid.
  • Inferior root: To the inferior belly of the omohyoid.
  • Note that the thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are supplied by separate branches from the first cervical nerve through the hypoglossal nerve.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume - 3, 8th Edition, Page Number 107,108.

questions.text: Earliest manifestation of end organ damage in chronic hypertension is:
questions.solution: Renal impairment is often the earliest manifestation of end organ damage in chronic hypertension. Proteinuria is commonly used to diagnose superimposed preeclampsia in cases of chronic hypertension during pregnancy.

questions.text: As per the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a mentally ill patient decides who is going to be his caretaker by___ .
questions.solution:
Advance Directive: Every person, who is not a minor, has a right to make an advance directive in writing, specifying:

  1. The way the person wishes to be cared or not to be cared for and treated for a mental illness.
  2. The individual or individuals, in order of precedence, he wants to appoint as his nominated representative.

Advance medical directive (also called living will): The Supreme court has recognised Advance medical directive (also called living will). It is the direction given by an adult in his conscious mind that, in future, if he/she becomes terminally ill and becomes an incompetent patient whether to give medical treatment or not.

Testamentary capacity (Testament = will): It is the mental ability of a person to make a valid will.

To make a valid will, it should have following components:

  • He should be a major.
  • The person should be of sound mind.
  • The person making Will should understand the nature of Will.
  • The person should have knowledge of his property that has to be disposed of.
  • The person should recognize the individuals who have moral claims to heir his property.

Palliative care: It is a specialized medical care that focuses on providing relief from pain and other symptoms of a serious illness.

Reference: Mental Health Care Act, 2017

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic middle ear infection now presents with neurological manifestations, headache & vomiting. CT brain is shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows an irregular hypodense lesion in the left temporal lobe, which is characteristic of a temporal lobe abscess. Neurological manifestations, headache, and vomiting in a patient with a history of chronic middle ear infection suggest intracranial complications, such as brain abscess.

Other options :

A. Extradural abscess: An extradural abscess is a collection of pus between the dura mater and the skull bone, usually related to sinusitis, but it would not involve the temporal lobe as shown in the CT scan.

B. Cerebral abscess: This is a collection of pus inside the brain. It is also not as likely to cause headache and vomiting as a temporal lobe abscess.

D. Meningitis: Meningitis is inflammation of the meninges, and its appearance on CT scan is different from what is shown in the image.

Reference: Textbook of ENT and Head & Neck Surgery by Hazarika, 4th Edition, Page Number-137.

Recurrence is common even after complete course

questions.text: Which level of prevention does the image indicate?
questions.solution:
LEVELS OF PREVENTION

(a) PRIMARY PREVENTION

  • This is the measure undertaken in the period of prepathogenesis (ie, before the development of the disease) which removes the possibility of occurrence of the disease. It is all the more important in those diseases, for which no treatment is available, eg, AIDS, Cancer, Rabies, Carries tooth, etc.
  • Primary prevention can be adopted by two modes of intervention:
    1. Health promotion and
    2. Specific
  • Health Promotion: This consists of 'general measures', which will strengthen the individual/ host and prevents the occurrence of the disease by interrupting the interaction among the three factors of epidemiological triad.
  • Specific Protection: This consists of 'specific measures', which prevent specific diseases.

(b) PRIMORDIAL PREVENTION

  • It is also a primary level of prevention of the disease but it is with reference to non- communicable diseases, such as obesity, hypertension, diabetes, cancer, coronary artery disease, etc. This consists of elimination or modification of 'risk factors' of the disease.

In such chronic, non-communicable diseases, the etiological (causative) agent is not known (or not established) and the etiology is discussed in terms of 'risk factors. 'They may act as contributory factors.

  • There are two approaches for the primordial prevention:
    1. Population(mass)strategy
    2. High-risk
  • Population Strategy: This is directed at the whole population, irrespective of individual risk level. For example, it is shown that a small reduction in the average blood pressure or serum cholesterol in the population, goes a long-way in reducing the prevalence of coronary artery disease in the community. This approach is directed towards changes in the life-style of the population by health education from the childhood itself. The results of these measures cannot be perceived immediately but are seen after several years or decades.
  • High-risk Strategy (Individual Strategy): This is directed to those individuals, who are at high risk of getting the disease. These high-risk group can be detected by screening procedures.

(c) SECONDARY PREVENTION

  • This is the measure undertaken in the early stage, after the onset of the disease or even much before the development of permanent pathology in the individual.
  • The intervention is by 'early diagnosis and ' This can be done by various screening procedures.
  • Early diagnosis and prompt treatment: This helps in the following ways:
    1. Helps in recovery from the disease(restoration)
    2. Reduces the duration of illness in the individual
    3. Minimizes the suffering
    4. Prevents the development of complications
    5. Prevents further spread of the diseases in the community
    6. Prevents or postpones the death of the

(d) TERTIARY PREVENTION

  • This is the measure undertaken, when the disease process is sufficiently advanced, (ie, in the late pathogenesis phase).
  • Tertiary prevention can be adopted by two modes of intervention:
    1. Disability limitation and
    2. Rehabilitation.
  • Disability Limitation: This means limiting the development of further disability in the individual by giving intensive or aggressive treatment, when the patient comes in the advanced stage of the disease. The objective is to prevent the transition from impairment to handicap.
  • Rehabilitation: This is the measure undertaken in the individual, when the disease is very much advanced and the patient experiences the disadvantage in the life and becomes disabled, handicapped and dependent. Rehabilitation is defined as

'Combined and coordinated use of physical, social, vocational and psychological measures for training and retraining the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability', so that the individual becomes useful to himself, to the family and to the community at large. In rehabilitation, it is essential to identify the remaining capacities in such an individual and adopt measures to make him fit, independent, productive, useful and active member in the family and community.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman of Northern European ancestry presents with progressive dyspnea (shortness of breath). She denies the use of cigarettes. Family history reveals that her sister also had problems with her lungs. Which one of the following etiologies most likely explains this patient's pulmonary symptoms?
questions.solution:
• α1-Antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency is a genetic disorder that can cause pulmonary damage and emphysema even in the absence of cigarette use.
  • A deficiency of AAT permits increased elastase activity to destroy elastin in the alveolar walls.
  • AAT deficiency should be suspected when chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
    develops in a patient younger than age 45 years who does not have a
    history of chronic bronchitis or tobacco use or when multiple family members develop obstructive lung disease at an early age.
  • Deficiency of vitamin C and deficiency of propyl hydroxylase are related to collagenase synthesis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:52, Page Number-645.

questions.text: Among the following the highest likelihood of developing pulmonary embolism as per Well's prediction rule is for?
Coxsackie A virus mainly causes all except___.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Coxsackie A virus causes aseptic meningitis more frequently. Hepatitis is associated with Coxsackie B.

Coxsackievirus A16 is part of a group of coxsackie viruses related to enteroviruses that belong to the Picornaviridae family of non-enveloped linear, positive sense single stranded RNA viruses as well as its genum enterovirus, which includes polio virus and echovirus. Coxsackievirus A16 is typically the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease in the USA. It is very contagious. They can pass from person to person by unwashed hands and contaminated surfaces. They can spread through droplets of fluid sprayed into the air when a person sneezes or coughs.

Treatment includes staying home, getting rest, and drinking plenty of fluids

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number-449.

questions.text: A patient presents with localized alopecia, poliosis, vitiligo, depigmented fundus appearance, and depigmented limbal lesions. What diagnosis is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Vogt Koyanagi Harada syndrome

  • Multi systemic disorder with auditory, central nervous system, skin, hair, and eye signs.
    1. CNS - Meningismus, cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis
    2. Skin - Alopecia, poliosis, vitiligo
    3. ENT - Sensory neural deafness, tinnitus
    4. Eye - Bilateral panuveitis, exudative retinal detachment
  • Siguira's sign : Perilimbal vitiligo

questions.text: Which injury can result from the mechanism shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The pulled elbow, also called nursemaid's elbow, is the subluxation of the radial head out from the annular ligament. It is caused by the axial traction on the extended arm, while the forearm is pronated such as when a child is pulled at the wrist to prevent a fall or is picked up from the floor by their hand.

The patient comes with the forearm in the pronated position and supination is resisted. The head is reduced by fully supinating and flexing the forearm, while applying direct pressure over the radial head.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-105.

questions.text: Which of the following is the microscopic finding in HPV associated with squamous cell cancer of the cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV type 16 has been associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the Cervix and with bowenoid papulosis.

HPV type 18 on the other hand is associated with Adenocarcinoma of the cervix.

Anogenital warts are caused predominantly by HPV types 6 and 11.

Classical feature of any HPV is koilocytes which has perinuclear halo

questions.text: A 2-day-old child was brought to the OPD with diffuse swelling over the scalp since birth. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Image shows blood collection in the scalp tissue, not extending intracranially. Hence, encephalocele gets ruled out.
  • Subgaleal hemorrhage has acute and morbid presentation and would not present in a routine OPD at 2 months.
  • Caput is soft tissue oedema that would disappear in about 48 hours after birth, crossing the midline.
  • Cephalohematoma can present over a long time with collection not crossing the suture lines.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-834.

questions.text: A 34 year old young male patient with mitral stenosis. He was admitted to the cardiology department and had to undergo a surgery. Pre-anesthetic checkup of him revealed increased liver enzymes. Which of the following inhalational agents should be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Xenon is the most preferred anesthetic in this case because among the available inhalational anesthetics, xenon is considered to have minimal effects on the cardiovascular system.

Even in patients with significant cardiac disease, xenon maintains a favorable profile.

Xenon is an inert gas and does not undergo metabolism. Therefore, it does not cause any hepatotoxicity or nephrotoxicity.

Xenon exerts anesthetic and analgesic effects at various receptors in CNS. The most important actions are Non-competitive antagonism of NMDA receptor, Agonism at the TREK channel (a member of two pore K+ channel family).

[Difficult]

[Clinical question]

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page Number-396.

Composite graft contains epidermis and only a part of dermis

questions.solution:

  • Full-thickness and composite grafts require the most careful handling and postoperative nursing to help ensure that they 'take' in their transplanted site.

FULL THICKNESS SKIN GRAFT

choices.text: Lower motor neuron paralysis of lower limb

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with conus medullaris syndrome. Which of the following symptoms is not seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Conus medullaris syndrome:

  • Due to injury to S2-S4 segments of spinal cord ( Lumbar part of vertebral column).
  • Features are:
  • Anaesthesia in the perineum. The region is supplied by these three segments.
  • Involvement of bladder and bowel is early as S2-S4 segments carry the sacral component of the parasympathetic system which supplies the bladder and lower bowel.
  • It cause UMN (upper motor neuron) type of paralysis which is spastic and associated with hyperreflexia. Only ankle jerk is affected.
  • Sexual functions are affected as same nerves carry out sexual functions.

Cauda Equina Syndrome on the other hand is due to involvement of lumbosacral nerve roots. Bladder involvement occurs later on in Cauda equina. Both knee and ankle jerks are lost, and it causes LMN type of paralysis which is asymmetric, areflexic and associated with atrophy.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page Number-29.

questions.text: In an infertile woman, the endometrial biopsy reveals proliferative changes. Which hormone should be preferred?
questions.solution: • In an infertile woman with proliferative changes on endometrial biopsy, the preferred hormone is MPA (Medroxyprogesterone acetate). MPA, a synthetic progesterone derivative, can be used to induce a secretory endometrium and support the luteal phase in cases of anovulation.

questions.text: Valid consent for sexual intercourse cannot be given by a girl aged less than:
questions.solution:
Minimum age of a girl to give consent for sexual intercourse is 18 years.

This was changed from 16 years to 18 years by the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013.

Reference: Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013.

questions.text: A 28 year old female has asymptomatic lesions on her face since 2 months. Her 2 year old daughter also has similar lesions. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Molluscum contagiosum virus causes characteristic skin lesions consisting of single or, more often, multiple, dome-shaped, pearly white umbilicated papules.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is a viral disease caused by a Molluscipox virus, dsDNA poxvirus.
  • Lesions are arranged in a linear pattern -pseudokoebners phenomena.
  • In adults, molluscum contagiosum most commonly is a sexually transmitted disease and more severe in HIV infected patients or chemotherapy/transplant patients.
  • T/t - self-limited and heals spontaneously in 6-9 months.
  • Although treatment is not required, it may help to reduce autoinoculation or transmission to close contacts and improves clinical appearance - cryotherapy or curettage.

Reference: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, Chapter 33, Page Number-33.

questions.text: What is this formula used to calculate?
questions.solution:
MEAN

  • The arithmetic mean is widely used in statistical To obtain the mean, the individual observations are first added together, and then divided by the number of observations. This central value has got highest utility in statistics. It represents the most appropriate measure of central tendency.
  • The advantages of the mean are that it is easy to calculate and
  • The disadvantages are that sometimes it may be unduly influenced by abnormal values in the The limitations of mean is that it is greatly affected by extreme values.
  • Nevertheless, the arithmetic mean is by far the most useful of the statistical

MEDIAN

  • The median is an average of a different kind, which does not depend upon the total and number of items. To obtain the median, the data is first arranged in an ascending or descending order of magnitude, and then the value of the middle observation is located, which is called the median.
  • It is easy to locate when there are odd number of values. When there are even number of values, the median is taken as the average of the two central values of the distribution series.
  • The advantage with the median value is that it is easily detected and much less disturbed by extreme values. The disadvantage is that it is not suitable for mathematical treatment.
  • Median is a better indicator of an attribute than mean when the lowest and the highest observations are wide apart or not so evenly distributed.

STANDARD DEVIATION

SD is the most common and generally most appropriate measure of dispersion. SD is defined as the 'root-mean-square (RMS) deviation of the values from their mean', or as the

square root of the variance.

When the sample size is more than 30, the above basic formula may be used without modification. For smaller samples, the above formula tends to

underestimate the standard deviation, and therefore needs correction, which is done by substituting the denominator (n-1) for n. The modified formula is as follows :

Interpretation of SD:

  • A large standard deviation means that data points are far from the mean
  • A small standard deviation means that data points are clustered closely around the mean

Uses of standard deviation:

  • It summarises the deviations of a large distribution from mean in one figure used as a unit of variation.
  • Indicates whether the variation of difference of an individual from the mean is by chance, i.e. natural or real due to some special reasons.
  • Helps in finding the standard error which determines whether the difference between means of two similar samples is by chance or real.
  • It also helps in finding the suitable size of sample for valid conclusions

VARIANCE (AND DEVIATION SCORES) Calculating variance (and standard deviation) involves the use of deviation scores. The deviation score of an element is found by subtracting the distribution's mean from the element. A deviation score is symbolised by the letter x (as opposed to X, which symbolises an element); so the formula for deviation scores is as follows: xXX =− For example, in a distribution with a mean of 16, an element of 23 would have a deviation score of (23 2 16) 5 7. On the same distribution, an element of 11 would have a deviation score of (11 2 16) 5 25. When calculating deviation scores for all the elements in a distribution, the results can be verified by checking that the sum of the deviation scores for all the elements is zero, that is, Σx 5 0. The variance of a distribution is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores in the distribution. The variance is therefore obtained by

  • finding the deviation score (x) for each element,
  • squaring each of these deviation scores (thus eliminating minus signs), and then
  • obtaining their mean in the usual way-by adding them all up and then dividing the total by their number

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition.

choices.text: The tense form of hemoglobin is more prevalent in the circulation of the fetus.
There is less 2,3-BPG in the fetal circulation as compared to maternal circulation.
Fetal hemoglobin binds 2,3-BPG with fewer ionic bonds than the adult form.
The oxygen-binding curve of fetal hemoglobin is shifted to the right.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is able to transfer oxygen to her fetus because fetal hemoglobin has a greater affinity for oxygen than does adult hemoglobin. Why is the affinity of fetal hemoglobin for oxygen higher?
questions.solution:
• In adult hemoglobin, 2,3-BPG binds to ionized residues in the interface between the two β-chains, thus decreasing the oxygen affinity. The γ-chains of fetal hemoglobin have fewer ionized residues in the corresponding interface and bind 2,3-BPG with less affinity, which allows for a greater binding affinity for oxygen.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Chapter No:3, Page Number-33.

questions.text: H1N1 is a type of__.
questions.solution:
Three types of influenza viruses are circulating in the world; A (H1N1), A ( H3N2) and B. A new type has been recognized as A ( H5N1). It causes an epidemic because of an antigenic shift that occurs in this virus. Antigenic drift is responsible for small outbreaks.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number-368.

questions.text: Identify the stage of TB hip.
questions.solution:
A/P radiograph of the pelvis and both hips that is showing a travelling or wandering right hip.

In stage IV of TB hip, there may be dislocation or subluxation of the hip joint, leading to the "wandering" or "travelling" appearance of the hip. This stage is characterized by severe destruction of the hip joint and surrounding structures.

The staging of TB of the hip typically follows the Gibbon classification, which includes four stages:

Stage I: Early infection with minimal radiographic changes.

Stage II: Osteolytic changes and joint involvement.

Stage III: Cold abscess formation.

Stage IV: Dislocation or subluxation of the hip joint.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics: Maheshwari & Mhaskar, 5th Edition, Page Number-448.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has been complaining of nausea, vomiting, dysphagia, and weight loss for a long time. General examination is normal except for signs of anemia. On upper GI endoscopy, a 3x2 cm ulcerated mass is noted in the antrum. Urease test is positive. An image from his gastric biopsy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Early symptoms of gastric adenocarcinoma resemble those of chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, including dyspepsia, dysphagia, and nausea. As a result, these tumours are often discovered at advanced stages, when symptoms such as weight loss, anorexia, early satiety (primarily in diffuse cancers), anaemia, and hemorrhage appear.

Positive urease test indicates H. pylori infection, which predisposes to gastric adenocarcinoma.

Image shows intestinal-type adenocarcinoma composed of columnar, gland-forming cells infiltrating through desmoplastic stroma.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 774-776.

questions.text: According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol, what is the chest compression to breathing ratio?
questions.solution:
The chest compression to ventilation (breathing) ratio in neonatal resuscitation is indeed 3:1. This means that after every three chest compressions, one ventilation is provided. The correct answer is option (a) 3:1. The rate of chest compressions is typically around 90 compressions per minute, and the recommended rate for ventilation is around 30 breaths per minute in neonatal resuscitation.

  • For resuscitation, chest compression to breathing ratio is 3:1.
  • Rate of chest compressions is 60/min.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-254.

questions.text: A 59 year old male patient was admitted to the emergency department for management of an acute asthmatic attack. His physician was treating him with frequent administration of salbutamol nebulizer. Which of the following adverse drug reactions is least likely to be attributed due to salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Muscle tremors are the dose related side effects.

Palpitation, restlessness, nervousness, throat irritation and ankle edema can also occur.

Hypokalemia is a possible complication.

  • Mnemonic [ HTTP]

Hypokalemia

Tremors

Tachycardia

Palpitations

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy reported to the sub-centre with complaints of fever and cough for 2 days. On examination, you notice chest indrawing. His respiratory rate is 38/min. What is the next step for management?
questions.solution:
IMNCI GUIDELINES

In the context of Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines, the management of a child with respiratory symptoms involves assessing the severity of illness and providing appropriate care.

In the given scenario, the child is 2 years old with fever and cough for 2 days, chest indrawing, and a respiratory rate of 38/min.

According to the latest IMNCI guidelines, either fast breathing or chest indrawing in a child suggests Pneumonia, which needs oral antibiotics.

Severe pneumonia is characterized by the presence of danger signs.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-871.

questions.text: A 25-year-old married nullipara undergoes laparoscopic cystectomy for an ovarian cyst, which on histopathology reveals ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution: In a young patient with ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma, where the disease is likely limited to the removed ovary (stage Ia), the next management is serial CA-125 measurement and follow-up. Fertility preservation can be considered, and the uterus and contralateral ovary can be preserved for women with stage Ia disease who desire to preserve fertility.

choices.text: If larger than 2mm, it is known as ecchymosis
These spots are reliable indicators of asphyxial death
Usually seen below the level of constriction

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding this postmortem finding on lungs in death due to asphyxia?
questions.solution:
The image shows Petechial hemorrhages (Tardieu spots).

Petechial hemorrhages

  • Usually round, dark, well defined, and about the size of a pinhead but may occasionally be larger
  • Vary in size from 0.1 mm to about 2 mm.
  • If larger than 2mm, it is known as ecchymosis.
  • Due to the rupture of venules (Option A).
  • Tardieu spots means, petechiae lying in the visceral pleura
  • Generally found in those parts where capillaries are least supported, E.g., Face, conjunctivae, epiglottis, heart and lung surfaces, brain, meninges and thymus
  • Usually seen above the level of constriction(e.g., strangulation) or compression (e.g., traumatic asphyxia) - Option D
  • Not a definite sign of asphyxia - Option C
    • May be found in other forms of deaths also, such as, Acute hemorrhage, Scurvy, Purpura, Haemophilia, Coronary thrombosis, Electric shock, Poisoning etc., but distribution is mainly general.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-101; Knight's Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition,

questions.text: A patient presented with concentric erythematous plaques with fine scales, resembling a wood-grain pattern. What is the most common underlying malignancy seen in the following skin condition?
questions.solution:
• Erythema gyratum repens is a rare, bizarre, cutaneous eruption consisting of mobile concentric, often palpable, erythematous, wave-like bands, which gives a ‘wood-grain’ appearance to the skin
  • Peripheral scales may be present.
  • The complete torso is frequently affected.
  • The lesions migrate from day to day, usually changing position by about 1 cm daily.
  • It has a strong association with internal malignancy (over 80% of cases), particularly lung cancer [1,2] which is present in about a third of cases; other cancer sites include esophagus, breast and few others.

Erythema gyratum repens Acanthosis nigricans Lesar trelat sign

Reference: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 2, Page Number-62.38.

questions.text: Which of these is false regarding an Indian reference woman?
questions.solution:
The false statement regarding the Indian reference woman is option (b): "50 kg weight."

(b) 50 kg weight: This statement is false. While there may be individual Indian women who weigh around 50 kg, it's not representative of the average weight for the reference woman in India. The weight of the reference woman is likely to be higher, considering factors such as height, age, and body composition.

Why the other options are correct:

(a) 19-39 yrs: This statement refers to the age range of the Indian reference woman. It is plausible as this age range typically represents the reproductive years for women, and reference values are often provided for this demographic to understand health and nutritional standards.

(c) 1.62m: This statement refers to the height of the Indian reference woman. It is plausible as this height falls within the typical range for adult women in India. However, it's essential to note that height can vary among individuals, but 1.62 meters is a common height cited for reference purposes.

(d) 20.9 BMI: This statement refers to the Body Mass Index (BMI) of the Indian reference woman. BMI is calculated by dividing weight in kilograms by the square of height in meters. A BMI of 20.9 falls within the healthy weight range for adults and is plausible for the reference woman in India.

In summary:

Options (a) (19-39 yrs), (c) (1.62m), and (d) (20.9 BMI) are likely to be true statements regarding the Indian reference woman. These values align with typical demographic characteristics and health standards for adult women in India.

Option (b) (50 kg weight) is false. While individual women may have this weight, it's not representative of the average weight for the reference woman in India.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man had a long history of skin cancer. In the past 6 years, he had over 30 neoplasms removed from sun-exposed areas and has been diagnosed with xeroderma pigmentosum. Which of the following best describes the enzymatic defect in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum?
questions.solution:
• Xeroderma pigmentosum is a genetic disease in which the ability to remove pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to UV light is impaired.
  • The mechanism used to remove these pyrimidine dimers (also used to repair DNA that has formed adducts with carcinogenic compounds) is excision repair.
  • The enzymes used in this repair mechanism cleave the affected strand on either side of damaged nucleotides.
  • The oligonucleotides, containing the damaged nucleotides are removed and the gap is filled in by DNA polymerase and DNA ligase.

Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32ndEdition, Chapter No:35, Page Number-380.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with complaints of left foot pain. She was awakened from sleep earlier in the day with intense pain near the head of the left great toe. The patient's medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals erythema, warmth, and swelling near the first metatarsophalangeal joint with marked tenderness to palpation. Which of the following tests will provide the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Synovial fluid analysis provides most accurate diagnosis of acute gout. During acute gout flares, needle-shaped MSU crystals typically are present both intracellularly and extracellularly. Under compensated polarized light, these crystals show bright, negative birefringence.

questions.text: Which among the following pathogens does not satisfy Koch's postulates?
questions.solution:
Koch's postulates

Robert Koch proposed a series of postulates that have been applied broadly to link many specific bacterial species with a particular disease.

1) Microorganisms should be found in all cases of the disease in question and its distribution in the body should be in accordance with the lesion observed.

2) Microorganisms should be grown in pure culture in vitro ( or outside the body of the host) for several generations.

3) When such a pure culture is inoculated into susceptible animal species, the typical disease must result.

4) The microorganism must again be isolated from the lesion of such experimentally produced disease.

Following microorganism does not follow Koch's postulates:

  • M leprae, T pallidum because these two cannot be cultured.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae - no animal model for experimental infection.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number-2.

questions.text: Flipping out of which phospholipid aids in recognition by macrophages for apoptosis?
questions.solution:
In healthy cells, phosphatidylserine is present on the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane, but in apoptotic cells this phospholipid “flips” out and is expressed on the outer layer of the membrane, where it is recognized by several macrophage receptors.

Option B: Phosphatidylcholine and sphingomyelin are overrepresented in the outer leaflet.

Option C: Phosphatidyl ethanolamine is predominantly found in the inner leaflet. It is an important precursor of other phospholipids.

Option D: Phosphatidylinositol on the inner membrane leaflet can be phosphorylated, serving as an electrostatic scaffold for intracellular proteins.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-46.

questions.text: Enzyme inhibitors like omeprazole can interfere with the activation of which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
Like ticlopidine, clopidogrel is also a prodrug. About 50% of the ingested dose is absorbed, and only a fraction of this is slowly activated in the liver by two step metabolism into an active thiol metabolite involving CYP2C19, while the rest is inactivated by other enzymes.

Since CYP2C19 exhibits genetic polymorphism, the activation of clopidogrel and consequently its antiplatelet action shows high interindividual variability. Some patients are nonresponsive.

Omeprazole, an inhibitor of CYP2C19, reduces metabolic activation of clopidogrel and its antiplatelet action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-678.

questions.text: Which among the following syndromes is caused by the mutation in the STK 11 gene?
questions.solution:
Peutz- Jeghers syndrome-

  • Caused by a mutation in STK11gene on chromosome 19.
  • Autosomal dominant

Clinical features -

  • Hyperpigmentationof buccal mucosa and lips.
  • Hamartomatous polypsthroughout the GI tract.
  • Increased risk of cancers (colorectal, stomach, breast).

questions.text: A 20-year female presents with an ovarian mass 6 x 6 x 6 cm in size. Ultrasonography reveals solid structures in the mass. Her serum biomarkers such as AFP, Beta-hCG, and CA 125 are normal; however, her serum alkaline phosphatase was found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In a young female with an ovarian mass, normal levels of AFP, Beta-hCG, and CA 125, along with an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, suggests the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas are germ cell tumors of the ovary and are known for their elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, which are indicative of an ovarian origin

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-202.

questions.text: Treatment of snakebite are all, except:
questions.solution:
Primary management (First aid) in a case of snake bite:

  • Best is immobilization → By application of splint
  • Assurance/Reassurance
  • Do not wash the area of the bite.
  • No tourniquet application.
  • Sutherland wrapping: Pressure application bycrepe bandage if the victim is expected to reach the hospital in more than 30 minutes, but less than 3 hours. The bandage is wrapped over the bitten area as well as the entire limb with the limb placed in a splint. It should be capable of admitting a finger beneath it.
  • Keep the affected area below heart level to reduce the flow of venom.
  • No incision & suction.
  • No ice application.
  • No electrotherapy.

Hospital treatment

  • Wait and watch for signs & symptoms.
  • If indicated → Begin PASV (Polyvalent anti snake venom) with 10 vials.
  • PASV is effective against 1. Common cobra, 2. Common krait, 3. Russel’s viper, and 4. Saw scaled viper
  • PASV produced by Hoffkine biopharmaceutical company neutralises venom of pit viper due to para-specific activity.

Fixation of toxins

  • Common cobra → neurotoxins get fixed at the postsynaptic Hence, neostigmine has a role.
  • Common krait → neurotoxins get fixed at the presynaptic Hence, neostigmine has norole.

Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/guidelines/nrhm-guidelines/stg/Snakebite_QRG.pdf http://repository-tnmgrmu.ac.in/18612/1/14110400021mohanraj.pdf

questions.text: St. Anthony's fire characterized by burning pain is due to:
questions.solution:
Ergot is the dried sclerotium of the fungus claviceps purpurea which grows on stale grains, particularly rye, barley, maize and wheat.

Fatal dose: 1-2 g.

Fatal period: Few days.

Chronic poisoning (ergotism) may either be convulsive or gangrenous in type.

  • In convulsive type, there is twitching, tingling, numbness and pain in the muscles. There may be headache, drowsiness, giddiness, formication and convulsions.
  • In gangrenous type, which resembles raynaud's disease, there is a burning pain (called St. Anthony's fire)in the limbs with alternating heat and cold sensation, numbness and tingling or anaesthesia. In fingers, toes, ears, nose, hands and feet, there may be dry gangrene without swelling and ulceration.

Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by Gautam Biswas, 5th Edition, Page Number-693.

questions.text: BMW rules were first made in India in the year:
questions.solution:
BMW rules were first made in India in 1998.

(c) 1998: This is the correct answer. The Biomedical Waste (Management and Handling) Rules were first introduced in India in 1998. These rules provided a comprehensive framework for the segregation, collection, treatment, and disposal of biomedical waste generated in healthcare facilities.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

(a) 1984: This option is incorrect because the BMW (Biomedical Waste) Rules were not first made in India in 1984. In fact, comprehensive rules for the management and handling of biomedical waste were not introduced until much later.

(b) 1991: This option is incorrect. While there were some efforts towards biomedical waste management in India in the early 1990s, including guidelines issued by the Ministry of Environment and Forests, the formal BMW rules were not established until later.

(c) 2000: This option is incorrect. By the year 2000, the BMW Rules were already in effect in India, having been established two years earlier in 1998. Therefore, 2000 cannot be the correct answer as it is after the implementation of the rules.

questions.text: Patient is on metoprolol and if he is given verapamil, what is the effect that occur ?
questions.solution: Both beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers cause AV block. So, the combination can cause significant bradycardia.

questions.text: What is the colour coding of the bag used in hospitals to dispose contaminated gloves ?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is (c). Red bags are usually reserved for hazardous or infectious waste, including materials contaminated with blood or other bodily fluids. While human anatomical waste may pose a risk of infection, red bags are primarily used for other types of hazardous waste in healthcare facilities.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

(a) Yellow: Yellow bags are used in hospitals to dispose of human anatomical wastes such as body parts.

(b) Black: Black bags are typically used for non-anatomical general waste in hospitals, such as food waste, packaging, and other non-infectious materials. They are not specifically designated for human anatomical waste.

(d) Blue: Blue bags are commonly used for recyclable materials or general non-hazardous waste in many hospitals. They are not specifically designated for human anatomical waste.

questions.text: A muscular, 25-year-old male, presents with dermatitis and an inflamed tongue. A history reveals that he has been consuming raw eggs as part of his training regimen for the past 6 months. Which vitamin function and reaction have been compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Raw eggs contain a protein, avidin, which binds biotin
  • Native avidin is resistant to hydrolysis by digestive proteases, when it binds biotin it prevents its absorption. Avidin that has been denatured by cooking will be broken down during the digestive process
  • Biotin is essential for carboxylation reaction.
  • Biotin deficiency manifests itself as an erythematous, scaly skin eruption and can also cause hair loss and conjunctivitis.

Reference:Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Chapter No:28, Page Number-385.

questions.text: A software engineer presents with fatigue. He is having a sedentary life, mostly sitting in front of a computer for 12-14 hours. He takes junk food, and is not eating vegetables and fruits. Hb 9, MCV 120. What is the most likely etiology ?
questions.solution: A diet poor in fresh vegetables is a major cause of folic acid deficiency. Cooked vegetables and meat are less satisfactory sources because cooking destroys much of the folate.

questions.text: Irradiation can be used to sterilize all the following, except:
questions.solution:
Endoscopes are sterilized by chemical methods;

  • Rigid endoscope - Autoclave
  • Flexible endoscope - Glutaraldehyde

Bone, tissue graft, and catgut sutures are sterilized by ionizing radiation (Gamma rays).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number-132.

questions.text: Which of the following is a telltale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation?
questions.solution:
Lipofuscin is composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids in complex with protein, suggesting that it is derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of intracellular membranes. Its importance lies in being a telltale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.

Option A: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived, golden yellow to-brown, granular, or crystalline pigment. It is one of the major storage forms of iron.

Option B: Melanin is an endogenous, brown-black, pigment formed when the enzyme tyrosinase catalyzes the oxidation of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine in melanocytes.

Option D: Homogentisic acid is a black pigment that occurs in patients with alkaptonuria, a rare metabolic disease. Here the pigment is deposited in the skin, connective tissue, and cartilage, and the pigmentation is known as ochronosis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 64-65.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate reason for discontinuation of progestin-only contraceptives by female patients?
questions.solution:
Episodes of irregular, unpredictable spotting and breakthrough bleeding are the most frequently encountered adverse effects and are the major reason why women discontinue use of progestin-only contraceptives.

No evidence indicates that progestin-only mini pill preparations increase thromboembolic events. They inhibit ovulation, so dysmenorrhea is not a side effect of progestin-only contraceptives. POPs do not decrease lactation and hence, are the preferred contraceptive of choice in the postpartum period.

Reference:Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number 348-350.

questions.text: All the following are clinical features of raised intracranial pressure except__.
questions.solution:
Symptoms of raised ICP include -

  • High pressure headache - worsens on coughing or bending forward.
  • Blurred vision or double vision.
  • Cranial nerve palsies.
  • Fundoscopy can detect papilledema. But, this takes time to develop and hence, may be absent in the acute phase.

Low pressure headaches, encountered after excessive cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drainage, are typically worse on standing.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-703.

questions.text: All the following are included in the triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus except
questions.solution:
• Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus typically presents with the triad of;
    • Gait disturbance,
    • Urinary incontinence and
    • Cognitive decline.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-704.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents with severe itching, particularly on the palms and soles, without any rash. On examination, there is no evidence of primary skin lesions. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Severe itching, especially on the palms and soles without a rash, is characteristic of cholestasis of pregnancy. This condition is associated with elevated serum bile acids and liver enzymes. Cholestasis of pregnancy poses a risk to the fetus and may lead to adverse outcomes, so close monitoring and management are essential

questions.text: One health assistant male/ female should be posted for a every:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is (c). One health assistant, whether male or female, should be posted for every 30,000 population. This is based on the standard guidelines for healthcare workforce allocation and distribution.

Why the other options are not correct:

(a) 5000 population: This option would result in a much higher ratio of health assistants to population compared to the recommended standard. Such a low ratio may not be efficient or cost-effective in terms of healthcare resource allocation.

(b) 20000 population: While this ratio would be an improvement over option A, it is still lower than the recommended standard of one health assistant for every 30,000 population. This could potentially lead to an inadequate distribution of healthcare personnel, resulting in underserved areas.

(d) 10000 population: Similar to option B, this ratio would also be lower than the recommended standard. Allocating one health assistant for every 10,000 population may result in healthcare disparities and unequal access to healthcare services across different regions or communities.

In summary, option (c) is the most appropriate choice based on established guidelines and standards for healthcare workforce distribution, ensuring more equitable access to healthcare services for the population.

questions.text: Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for population of:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is (a). Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) workers are proposed to work for a population range of 1000-2500.

Why the other options are not correct:

(b) 2500-3500: This range is slightly higher than the proposed range for USHA workers. While some flexibility might exist in practice, it's generally recommended for USHA workers to serve smaller populations to ensure effective coverage and personalized care.

(c) 4000-5000: This range exceeds the proposed range for USHA workers. Assigning USHA workers to populations of this size might stretch their resources thin and compromise the quality of care they can provide.

(d) 5000-10000: This range is significantly larger than the proposed range for USHA workers. It would be challenging for USHA workers to effectively address the healthcare needs of such large populations while maintaining personalized care and accessibility.

In summary, option (a) aligns with the proposed population range for USHA workers, ensuring that they can deliver quality healthcare services to their assigned communities effectively.

questions.text: Many genetic diseases such as cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia can be diagnosed by detecting restriction fragment length polymorphisms (RFLPs). Which of the following is most likely to be used in an RFLP analysis?
questions.solution:
• Restriction length fragment polymorphism analysis detects mutations in the DNA that either introduce or eliminate a recognition site for a restriction enzyme.
  • This is detected by performing a Southern blot analysis on patient DNA after incubation with a specific restriction enzyme and comparing it to one performed on DNA obtained from a normal gene.
  • Remember:
  • Northern Blot: RNA (Roti is famous in North)
  • Sothern Blot: DNA (Dosa is famous in South)
  • Western Blot: Protein (Pizza is famous in Western)

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th Edition, Chapter No:34, Page Number-491.

questions.text: Which test is the most specific for diagnosing limited cutaneous scleroderma?

V. Parahemolyticus shows the kanagawa phenomenon on wagatsuma agar. It grows in upto 8% salt solution, shows swarming growth on blood agar. It is known to cause invasive diarrhea after consumption of seafood.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with Kawasaki disease is admitted in the ICU with severe sepsis. His peripheral smear shows neutrophils with blue cytoplasmic patches as shown below. What are these structures known as?
questions.solution:
This smear from a patient with bacterial sepsis shows neutrophils containing coarse purple cytoplasmic granules (toxic granulations) and blue cytoplasmic patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum (Dohle bodies) (arrow).

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese woman complains of post-menopausal bleeding for 3 months. There is no enlargement of uterus, and cervix appears normal on pelvic examination. D&C is done and the biopsy shows findings consistent with adenocarcinoma. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Endometrioid endometrial carcinoma typically arises in the setting of endometrial hyperplasia, and, like endometrial hyperplasia, is associated with conditions in which unopposed estrogenic stimulation of the endometrium occurs. Most notable of these is obesity, a rapidly increasing problem in high income countries.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 1008-1009.

questions.text: A 56 year old diabetic female patient was started on a drug that decreased her HbA1c from 7.6 to 6.8. After a few weeks of starting the medicine, she started complaining of itching around the vulvo-vaginal area with suspected mycotic infections. Which amongst the following is the most likely drug she was using?
questions.solution:
Canagliflozin

These SGLT-2 inhibitors are approved for use in type 2 DM patients.

After once daily dosing, they produce round-the-clock glucosuria and lower blood glucose levels.

Used alone or in combination with other antidiabetic drugs, they reduce HbA1C levels by 0.5-1.0%, but do not cause hypoglycemia.

The concerns which appear inbuilt due to their mechanism of action are-glycosuria, which can predispose to urinary and genital infections, electrolyte imbalance, ketoacidosis and increased urinary frequency.

They are contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-301.

questions.text: Which among the following terminologies denotes the transplant of graft between different species?
questions.solution:
Xenograft is a graft performed between different species. Some common terminologies in organ transplantation include -

  • Allograft - An organ or tissue transplanted from one individual to another.
  • Xenograft - A graft performed between different species.
  • Orthotopic graft - A graft placed in its normal anatomical site.
  • Heterotopic graft - A graft placed in a site different from that where the organ is normally located.
  • Alloantigen - Transplant antigen.
  • Alloantibody -Transplant antibodies.
  • HLA (Human Leukocyte Antigen) - The main trigger to graft rejection.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th Edition, Page Number-1533

questions.text: Which among the following arteries does not supply blood to the breast?
questions.solution:
Arterial Blood Supply:

  1. Internal Thoracic Artery: It is a branch of the subclavian artery, and it supplies the mammary gland through its perforating branches.
  2. Axillary Artery: Several branches of the axillary artery provide blood supply to the breast. These include the lateral thoracic artery, superior thoracic artery, and acromiothoracic (thoracoacromial) artery.
  3. Posterior Intercostal Arteries: Lateral branches of the posterior intercostal arteries also contribute to the blood supply of the mammary gland. These arteries distribute blood to the breast primarily from its anterior surface.

Venous Drainage:

  1. Superficial Veins: These veins gather and drain blood from the mammary gland towards the base of the nipple. They form an anastomotic venous circle at this point.
    • From there, the superficial veins connect to the internal thoracic vein.
    • They may also connect to the superficial veins in the lower part of the neck.
  2. Deep Veins: The deep veins of the breast drain into major venous pathways.
    • They typically drain into the axillary vein.
    • Some deep veins may connect to the posterior intercostal veins.

This vascular arrangement ensures that the mammary gland receives an adequate blood supply, primarily from the front (anterior surface) of the breast. The posterior surface is relatively less vascular.

Reference: Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page Number-545.

questions.text: N-acetyl-p- benzoquinone imine causes hepatic necrosis in poisoning with ?
questions.solution: Acetaminophen is metabolized predominantly by a phase II reac- tion to innocuous sulfate and glucuronide metabolites; however, a small proportion is metabolized by a phase I reaction to a hepatotoxic metabolite formed from the parent compound by cytochrome P450 CYP2E1. This metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI), is detoxified by binding to 'hepatoprotective' glutathione to become harmless, water-soluble mercapturic acid, which undergoes renal excretion. When excessive amounts of NAPQI are formed, or when glutathione levels are low, glutathione levels are depleted and over- whelmed, permitting covalent binding to nucleophilic hepatocyte macromolecules forming acetaminophen-protein 'adducts.', which causes hepatic necrosis.

questions.text: All the following organisms cause food poisoning in 6-7 hours except__.
questions.solution:
A) Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus aureus is known to produce toxins that can cause rapid-onset food poisoning. The symptoms typically appear within a few hours (usually 1-6 hours) after consuming contaminated food. Therefore, staphylococcus is not the correct answer based on the given statement.

B) coli (Escherichia coli): Certain strains of E. coli, such as E. coli O157:H7, can produce toxins that cause food poisoning. The incubation period for E. coli food poisoning is generally longer than 6-7 hours, often ranging from 1 to 8 days or more. Therefore, E. coli is consistent with the statement.

C) Clostridium: Clostridium perfringens is a bacterium that produces toxins causing food poisoning. The incubation period for clostridium perfringens food poisoning is relatively short, typically around 6-24 hours. Therefore, clostridium is consistent with the statement.

D) Bacillus cereus: Bacillus cereus is associated with two types of food poisoning: one with a rapid onset (emetic type) and one with a longer incubation period (diarrheal type). The emetic type, which causes symptoms within a few hours (2-6 hours), is not consistent with the statement. Therefore, the correct answer based on the given statement is D) Bacillus cereus. Food poisoning caused by bacillus cereus (diarrheal type) can occur after 8-16 hrs, so it does not fit the pattern of the other bacteria listed.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number 494-95.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most suitably used for trastuzumab resistant metastatic Her-2 positive breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Lapatinib

This is a synthetic orally active inhibitor of EGFR/HER2 which penetrates cells and blocks tyrosine kinase activity of the liganded HER2 and thus, interferes with signal transduction.

Lapatinib is indicated in metastatic HER2 positive breast cancer that is nonresponsive to trastuzumab and is used in combination with capecitabine.

Adverse effects are fatigue, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, decreased LVEF, heart failure and Q-T prolongation. However, lapatinib is considered to be less cardiotoxic than trastuzumab

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-930.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of hypothyroidism in the iodine replete population?
questions.solution:
Autoimmune Thyroiditis

  • Autoimmune thyroiditis is the most frequent cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-replete populations.
  • The most common type is chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, otherwise known as Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • This disorder is found predominantly in females at upto a 10:1 female-to-male incidence ratio.
  • In addition, there is a strong hereditary component, with first-degree relatives of Hashimoto's patients having a nine-fold risk of also developing the disease.
  • The etiology of Hashimoto thyroiditis is due to the presence of circulating autoantibodies to thyroid antigens, resulting in a chronic autoimmune destructive process involving the formation of immune complexes and complement in the basement membrane of follicular cells.
  • This leads to the infiltration of lymphocytes into the thyroid follicles and eventually results in fibrosis, which decreases the effective number of follicles needed to produce thyroid hormones.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page Number-884

questions.text: Which among the following pouches develop the parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
• Embryology of the thyroid and parathyroid glands underlies the anatomical position, anatomical variations and congenital conditions of these structures and is therefore vital for surgery.
  • The thyroglossal duct develops from the median bud of the pharynx.
  • The foramen caecum at the junction of the anterior two-thirds and posterior one-third of the tongue is the vestigial remnant of the duct.
  • This initially hollow structure migrates caudally and passes in close continuity with, and sometimes through, the developing hyoid cartilage.
  • The parathyroid glands develop from the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • The thymus also develops from the third pouch.
  • As it descends, the thymus takes the associated parathyroid gland with it, which explains why the inferior parathyroid, which arises from the third pharyngeal pouch, normally lies inferior to the superior gland.
  • However, the inferior parathyroid may be found anywhere along this line of descent.
  • The developing thyroid lobes amalgamate with the structures that arise in the fourth pharyngeal pouch, i.e. the superior parathyroid gland and the ultimobranchial body.
  • Parafollicular cells (C cells) from the neural crest reach the thyroid via the ultimobranchial body.

 Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-850.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department unconscious by emergency medical services. His wife reports finding him unresponsive in their garage, where he was running a generator due to a power outage caused by a recent storm. On examination, he appears cyanotic, and his skin has a cherry-red coloration. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a significant elevation in carboxyhaemoglobin levels. What is the primary mechanism of toxicity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Justification:

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning occurs due to the inhalation of carbon monoxide gas, which has a very high affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin (CO-Hb) and reducing oxygen delivery to tissues (hypoxia).
  • It is a colorless and odorless gas, and may arise from internal combustion engines, fossil-fuelled home appliances (heaters, furnaces, stoves). It does not give warning signs.
  • The cherry-red skin coloration seen in CO poisoning is due to the formation of CO-Hb.
  • Additionally, CO can also bind to cytochrome oxidase, inhibiting mitochondrial respiration, and further exacerbating tissue hypoxia.
  • This inhibition of cytochrome oxidase disrupts cellular metabolism, particularly in tissues with high oxygen demand such as the brain and heart, leading to cellular dysfunction and death.
  • Treatment is thus 100 percent O2 to displace the CO from the hemoglobin.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:06, Page Number-51

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was brought to the medicine department with a worsening heart condition. Which of the following anti diabetic agents is most suitable for her established heart failure with reduced ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide

The liraglutide peptide is a long-acting, DPP-4-resistant form of GLP-1. It has extended t1/2 that permits once-daily administration.

The pharmacodynamic profile of liraglutide mimics GLP-1 and exenatide. In clinical trials, liraglutide caused both improvement in glycemic control and weight loss.

In a recent report, liraglutide reduced the risk of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or nonfatal stroke in patients with type 2 diabetes and established cardiovascular disease.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page Number-877.

questions.text: Normal life span of a mosquito is:
questions.solution:
The normal lifespan of a mosquito can vary depending on factors such as species, environmental conditions, and availability of food sources. However, typically, the lifespan of adult mosquitoes ranges from several days to a few weeks.

(c) 8-34 days:

This option represents a more realistic range for the lifespan of adult mosquitoes. Depending on the species and environmental factors, mosquitoes may live anywhere from a week to several weeks. The upper limit of 34 days may apply to certain species living under favourable conditions.

Why the other options are not suitable:

(a) 2-3 days:

- This option represents a very short lifespan for a mosquito. While some species of mosquitoes may have an exceptionally brief lifespan under specific conditions, such as adverse environmental factors or lack of food sources, an average lifespan of 2-3 days is uncommon for most mosquito species.

(b) 5-7 days:

This option suggests a slightly longer lifespan for mosquitoes compared to option A. While some mosquitoes may live for about a week, this timeframe is relatively short compared to the potential lifespan of mosquitoes under optimal conditions.

(d) 3-4 months:

This option overestimates the typical lifespan of a mosquito. While some species of mosquitoes may have longer lifespans, particularly in laboratory settings or under ideal conditions, the average lifespan of mosquitoes in the wild is generally much shorter than 3-4 months.

Option C, 8-34 days, is the most accurate representation of the normal lifespan of a mosquito. While some mosquitoes may live for only a few days, others may survive for several weeks under optimal conditions. Options A, B, and D either underestimate or overestimate the typical lifespan of mosquitoes. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She reports that these symptoms started suddenly yesterday evening and have been progressively worsening. On examination, she appears uncomfortable and writhing in pain. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness with guarding, especially in the epigastric region. Neurological examination is unremarkable. The hallmark laboratory findings were increase of urinary δ-amino levulinate and porphobilinogen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase (also known as hydroxymethylbilane synthase), leading to the accumulation of porphyrin precursors, particularly porphobilinogen.
  • Patients typically present with acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes neurological symptoms during acute attacks.
  • The hallmark laboratory findings were increases of urinary δ-aminolevulinate and porphobilinogen.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:31, Page No

questions.text: Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) can be caused by the transfusion of:
questions.solution: TRALI is characterized by the occurrence or worsening of hypoxia and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema with bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray during or within 6 h after transfusion, although delayed cases may occur up to 72 h later. TRALI may be difficult to distinguish from other causes of hypoxia, such as circulatory over- load, and is among the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. questions.text: A 34 year old pregnant female with a history of lepromatous leprosy with ongoing treatment with anti-leprotic drugs presents to the medicine OPD with type II lepra reaction. Which of the following is the immediate management of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Reactions in leprosy

Lepra reaction This occurs in LL, usually coincides with the institution of chemotherapy and/or intercurrent infection. It is a Jarisch Herxheimer

(Arthus) type of reaction due to release of antigens from the killed bacilli, and may be mild, severe or life-threatening, i.e. erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL). Temporary discontinuation of dapsone is recommended only in severe cases. Clofazimine (200 mg daily) is effective in controlling the reaction (except the severe one), probably because of its antiinflammatory property. For severe reactions, prednisolone 40–60 mg/day is started immediately and continued till the reaction subsides. The dose is then tapered over 2–3 months.

Thalidomide- It is an anti inflammatory cytokine (TNFα, ILs, interferon) modulating drug with anxiolytic, antiemetic property. Thalidomide can be used in ENL as an alternative to prednisolone.

Reversal reaction This is seen in TT and BL cases, and is a manifestation of delayed hypersensitivity to M. leprae antigens. Cutaneous ulceration, multiple nerve involvement with swollen, painful and tender nerves occurs suddenly even after completion of therapy. Reversal reaction is treated with clofazimine or corticosteroids in the same way as ENL, but thalidomide is ineffective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-837.

questions.text: Arrange the following phases of disaster cycle in a logical sequence.
questions.solution:
Disaster Impact: This is the initial phase where the disaster event occurs, resulting in immediate consequences such as loss of life, injury, damage to infrastructure, and disruption of essential services.

Response: Following the disaster impact, emergency response efforts are initiated to address the immediate needs of affected populations. This includes search and rescue operations, medical assistance, provision of food, water, shelter, and other humanitarian aid.

Rehabilitation: Once the immediate response phase is completed, the focus shifts to rehabilitation. During this phase, efforts are made to restore essential services, infrastructure, and livelihoods, as well as to provide support for long-term recovery and reconstruction.

Mitigation: The final phase of the disaster cycle involves implementing measures to reduce the risk of future disasters and minimize their impact. This includes activities such as building resilient infrastructure, implementing early warning systems, improving land-use planning, and enhancing community preparedness and capacity.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

(a) Disaster impact-mitigation-rehabilitation-response:

This sequence does not follow a logical order. Mitigation efforts typically occur before a disaster impact to reduce its severity or likelihood. Therefore, placing mitigation after disaster impact is not appropriate.

(c) Rehabilitation-response-disaster impact-mitigation:

This sequence also does not follow a logical order. Rehabilitation typically occurs after the response phase to address the long-term recovery needs of affected communities. Placing rehabilitation before the disaster impact is illogical.

(d) Response-disaster impact-rehabilitation-mitigation:

This sequence starts with the response phase, which is appropriate. However, placing disaster impact before the response phase is not logical, as the impact occurs before the response is initiated. Additionally, mitigation efforts are typically implemented before disaster impact, not after rehabilitation. Therefore, this sequence is not correct.

choices.text: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to renal resistance to vasopressin action.

Primary polydipsia due to excessive fluid intake leading to dilutional hyponatremia

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of polyuria and polydipsia. He reports that these symptoms have been ongoing for several months. The patient's medical history is significant for a pituitary tumour, which was surgically removed two years ago. He denies any recent head trauma or significant medical conditions. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory tests show low urine specific gravity and osmolality, while serum sodium levels are elevated. Serum levels of vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) are undetectable. Which type of diabetes insipidus is most likely affecting this patient, and what is the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Given the patient's history of pituitary tumour removal and undetectable serum levels of vasopressin, the most likely diagnosis is central diabetes insipidus.
  • Central diabetes insipidus results from damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland, leading to decreased secretion of vasopressin.
  • This leads to impaired water reabsorption in the kidneys, resulting in dilute urine and hypernatremia.
  • The absence of head trauma or other significant medical conditions supports the diagnosis of central rather than nephrogenic diabetes insipidus or gestational diabetes insipidus. Additionally, primary polydipsia is less likely, given the absence of a history of excessive fluid intake.

Reference: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter No:40, Page Number-479.
