Anorexia, nausea, vomiting, salivation, metallic taste, epigastric discomfort, sulfurous belching and hepatitis.

It also causes aches and pains, peripheral neuritis, behavioural changes, rashes, impotence, menstrual disturbances and goiter on prolonged use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-821.

questions.text: What is the behaviour of the suture material which returns to its original length once the tension is released?
questions.solution:
Tensile behaviour- Suture materials behave differently depending upon their deformability and flexibility.

  • Some may be 'elastic', where the material will return to its original length once any tension is released, while others may be 'plastic', in which case this phenomenon does not occur.
  • Sutures may be deformable, in that a circular cross-section may be converted to an oval shape, or they may be more rigid and have the somewhat irritating capacity to kink and coil.
  • Many synthetic materials demonstrate 'memory', so that they keep curling up in the shape they adopted within the packaging.
  • A sharp but gentle pull on the suture material helps to diminish this memory, but the more memory a suture material has, the lower is the knot security.
  • Therefore, knotting technique also plays a significant role in any suture line's tensile strength and it is important to recognise that sutures lose 50% of their strength at the knot.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th Edition, Page Number-90.

choices.text: To match the limited resources with many problems
To develop the best course of action to accomplish a defined objective

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains the purpose of planning?
questions.solution:
• Option (c)- To develop the best course of action to accomplish a defined objective**: This statement best explains the purpose of planning. Planning involves analyzing various alternatives, assessing risks, and determining the most effective and efficient course of action to achieve specific objectives. It helps in setting priorities, allocating resources appropriately, and establishing timelines to ensure that objectives are met in the most optimal way

Explanation for why not the other options:

  • Option (a) - To match limited resources with many problems: While planning does involve allocating resources efficiently, its primary purpose is not just to match resources with problems. Planning is about developing a systematic approach to achieve specific goals or objectives, which may involve addressing problems, but it goes beyond simply matching resources with problems.
  • Option (b)- To eliminate wasteful expenditure: While planning can certainly help in identifying and reducing wasteful expenditure by allocating resources more effectively, this statement does not fully capture the comprehensive purpose of planning. Planning involves more than just cost management; it encompasses the strategic alignment of resources to achieve organisational objectives.
  • Option (d) - All of the above: While options A and B may be considered aspects of planning, they are not the sole purposes of planning. Planning involves a broader scope of activities beyond just matching resources with problems or eliminating wasteful expenditure. Therefore, option C, which emphasizes developing the best course of action to achieve objectives, is the most accurate representation of the purpose of planning.

questions.text: A patient with a lung mass has hypercalcemia. What is the likely cause ?
questions.solution: Squamous cell carcinoma can produce hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic manifestation.

questions.text:
A 50 year old man who is a chronic smoker presented with pain in the right arm. There is also evidence of ptosis. Chest Xray is given below.


What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Pancoast (or superior sulcus tumor) syndrome result from local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung with involvement of the eighth cervical and first and second thoracic nerves, and present with shoulder pain that characteristically radiates in the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with radiologic destruction of the first and second ribs. Often Horner’s syndrome and Pancoast syndrome coexist. Other problems of regional spread include superior vena cava syndrome from vascular obstruction; pericardial and cardiac extension with resultant tamponade, arrhythmia, or cardiac failure; lymphatic obstruction with resultant pleural effusion; and lymphangitic spread through the lungs with hypoxemia and dyspnea.

questions.text: All the following can be seen in refeeding syndrome except__.
questions.solution:
This is characterized by shift in fluid and electrolyte shift in malnourished patients undergoing refeeding. It is more common with parenteral fluids. It results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-338.

questions.text: What is the time range for air exchange in laminar airflow theatres?
questions.solution:
• Ultra-clean ventilation systems use high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters that remove 99.9% of particulate matter >0.3 mm in diameter (bacteria are 0.5 mm).
  • They also use vertical laminar airflow over the operating table to minimise turbulence, reduce contamination at the surgical site (horizontal laminar air flow is less effective (Salvati et al. 1982)).
  • Laminar airflow theatres have an air exchange every 2-3 minutes.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th Edition, Page Number-1563.

questions.text: Most common type of MODY is:
questions.solution: Most common type of MODY is type 3.

questions.text: Remifentanyl is an ideal drug for total intravenous anesthesia because of which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Due to its ester linkages, it is susceptible to hydrolysis by blood and tissue non specific esterases resulting in rapid metabolism. This allows rapid termination of the effect and referral from anesthesia.

  • Highly lipid soluble
  • Pharmacokinetics uninfluenced by liver and renal failure.
  • Context sensitive half time is around 4 minutes and is independent of the duration of infusion.

In blood, remifentanil is metabolized primarily by enzymes within erythrocytes. Remifentanil is not a good substrate for pseudocholinesterase and therefore, is not influenced by pseudocholinesterase deficiency.

Reference: Miller's Anaesthesia, 8th Edition, Page Number-1035.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents to the hospital with new orthopnea. His blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 96 beats per minute. He has clear lungs, a displaced cardiac apex with a third heart sound but no cardiac murmurs, and no lower extremity edema. Laboratory test results were as follows: hemoglobin 14 g/dL, sodium 137 mEq/L, potassium 4.4 mEq/L, and serum creatinine 1.7 mg/dL. Chest radiography shows pulmonary congestion with cardiomegaly. The ECG shows sinus rhythm, nonspecific ST-T changes, and frequent premature ventricular complexes. Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 20% and a dilated left ventricle. What should be the next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution: The clinical scenario is that of a dilated cardiomyopathy. In view of the co-existing co-morbidities, this is likely to be a coronary artery disease that results in a ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy. So, next step will be coronary angiography.

questions.text: A postnatal mother who delivered 20 days back presents with increased tearfulness and sleeplessness. There are features of anhedonia, suicidal tendency. She claims that her baby is not the real one as someone has already stolen the baby from her womb. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with confusion, and headache. Blood pressure is found to be 220/105 mm Hg. Physical examination is notable for skin thickening of the arms and legs, facial telangiectasias, and decreased oral aperture. Laboratory studies show a creatinine of 3.5 mg/dL. What is the appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution: The clinical scenario is suggestive of scleroderma renal crisis. Drug of choice for scleroderma renal crisis is ACE inhibitor.

questions.text: A pediatric patient presented to the emergency department with severe vomiting and blood in stools. He underwent an USG of the abdomen. The image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Upon scrutinizing the provided USG image, the characteristic target sign emerges, strongly indicative of intussusception. In pediatric patients, intussusception involves the telescoping or invagination of one portion of the intestine into another, resulting in bowel obstruction. The clinical presentation with severe vomiting and blood in stools aligns with the classic symptoms of intussusception in children.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI'as Comprehensive Textbook of Diagnostic Radiology, 2nd Edition, Page no 1144

questions.text: Broad casts in urinary sediment is diagnostic of which of the following conditions ?
questions.solution: Casts can be seen in chronic renal diseases. Degenerated cellular casts called waxy casts or broad casts (arising in the dilated tubules that have undergone compensatory hypertrophy in response to reduced renal mass) may be seen in the urine.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient was admitted to hospital for acute abdominal infection. He has a history of liver failure. His physician has prescribed cephalosporin to tackle the infection. Which amongst the following cephalosporins should be avoided in patients with hepatic failure?
questions.solution:
Cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. All cephalosporins need dose reduction in renal failure except cefoperazone, which has predominant biliary excretion.

Dose reduction is necessary for hepatic impairment for cefoperazone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-778.

questions.text: Which of the following renal stones form only when the upper urinary tract is infected with urease producing bacteria ?
questions.solution: Struvite stones, also known as infection stones or triple- phosphate stones, form only when the upper urinary tract is infected with urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, or Providencia species. Urease produced by these bacteria hydrolyzes urea and may elevate the urine pH to a supraphysiologic level (>8.0). Struvite stones may grow quickly and fill the renal pelvis (staghorn calculi)

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient comes to you for follow up with apprehension of passing brown colour urine. He was prescribed a regimen of antimicrobial for urinary tract infection 3 days back. He also complains of fever with chills and chest pain that started after he had started the medications. The most likely antimicrobial agent prescribed in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects Nitrofurantoin

Commonest is gastrointestinal intolerance - nausea, epigastric pain and diarrhoea.

An acute reaction with chills, fever and leukopenia occurs occasionally.

Peripheral neuritis and other neurological effects are reported with long-term use. Haemolytic anemia is rare, except in G-6-PD deficiency.

Liver damage and a pulmonary reaction with fibrosis on chronic use are infrequent events.

Urine of patients taking nitrofurantoin turns dark brown on exposure to air.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number- 810.

questions.text: A 40 year old patient was admitted with status epilepticus. During hospital stay, patient developed fever, myalgia and reddish brown discoloration of urine. Dipstick is positive for hemoglobin. Urine routine does not show any sediments. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Status epilepticus can lead onto rhabdomyolysis. The characteristic triad of complaints in rhabdomyolysis is muscle pain, weakness, and dark urine. Myoglobin may show false positive dipstick test for hemoglobin.

questions.text: In case of blood loss, which is the ideal replacement fluid?
questions.solution:
In case of blood loss, blood products are the ideal replacement fluids as crystalloids and colloids have no oxygen carrying capacity and do not contain coagulation factors, RBCs etc.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page Number-21.
